Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM6131 - Leadership","description":"

NOTE: This course was identified as MBAX9131 prior to 2022.


This course is a comprehensive introduction to the topic of leadership. It aims to help students to build the confidence, knowledge and skills to engage in effective leadership in a broad range of contexts. It also provides guidance on self-leadership and actively managing the process of growing as a leader.


The course defines ‘leadership’ not as a position but as a process of influence that delivers direction, alignment of activities towards that direction, and personal commitment to collective success. As such, leadership is potentially relevant to all MBA students who wish to exert influence and drive change.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was identified as MBAX9131 prior to 2022.

This course is a comprehensive introduction to the topic of leadership. It aims to help students to build the confidence, knowledge and skills to engage in effective leadership in a broad range of contexts. It also provides guidance on self-leadership and actively managing the process of growing as a leader.

The course defines ‘leadership’ not as a position but as a process of influence that delivers direction, alignment of activities towards that direction, and personal commitment to collective success. As such, leadership is potentially relevant to all MBA students who wish to exert influence and drive change.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM6143 - Strategy","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9143.


The Strategy course aims to equip students with the skills, knowledge and experience to formulate, evaluate and implement value-creating strategies for organisations. The course introduces students to the contemporary principles, tools and frameworks of strategic management that support the work of successful strategists in leading sustainable organisations. Whether students work in small or large organisations, whether in a startup, scale up or incumbent, domestically focused or a major international or global organisation, in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors, strategic management plays a central role in achieving the objectives of the organisation as we navigate an increasingly complex, disrupted, technology-infused, and dynamic business environment.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9143.

The Strategy course aims to equip students with the skills, knowledge and experience to formulate, evaluate and implement value-creating strategies for organisations. The course introduces students to the contemporary principles, tools and frameworks of strategic management that support the work of successful strategists in leading sustainable organisations. Whether students work in small or large organisations, whether in a startup, scale up or incumbent, domestically focused or a major international or global organisation, in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors, strategic management plays a central role in achieving the objectives of the organisation as we navigate an increasingly complex, disrupted, technology-infused, and dynamic business environment.
contentlets.title: Strategy

Management","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6210.


The course provides a broad introduction to all aspects of the accounting function. The language of accounting and financial management is exacting. Our aim is to increase your familiarity with key components of this language and allow you to more effectively communicate with all organisational stakeholders. Users of accounting information may be typically classified as either external users (such as investors) or internal users (such as operational managers). Different users have different information needs. This course deals with the needs of these two main user groups and how the senior management of organisations can more effectively use accounting data to connect with them.


The subject will explore accounting techniques and terminology to equip students with sufficient conceptual and practical skills to make them, and any professional who may advise them, confident in their ability to understand and communicate complex financial strategies.


This subject also examines the design and operation of accounting systems. As a result, the course integrates ideas and concepts from accounting with a range of other disciplines and reveals how the effective use of financial information provided by such systems can improve organisational decision-making.


It is assumed that students have little prior knowledge of accounting and financial management.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c3bc0c66db617050be4672f5f39619db","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Online Quiz 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 to 4.

It is primarily calculation-based and asks participants to apply their understanding of the components of the three primary financial statements, accrual accounting and the accounting equation.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 12 multiple-choice questions and a calculation-based question. The calculation-based question has multiple components. The duration of the quiz is 60 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the quiz at 7.30pm, in which case you would finish at 8.30pm).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"07bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Online Quiz 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 to 10.

It contains both calculation-based questions and discursive questions and asks participants to apply their understanding of the components of financial accounting and the primary elements of management accounting.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 12 multiple-choice questions (these are primarily drawn from Units 6 to 10) and two calculation-based questions - one based on financial accounting and the second based on the application of management accounting practice. Each of the two calculation-based question have multiple components. The duration of the exam is 90 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the exam at 7pm, in which case you would finish at 8.30pm).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"07bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4bbc4c66db617050be4672f5f396196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Calculation and Description of Accounting Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to create and comment on a set of financial reports. This is a team based assignment and details of how to form teams will be discussed 'in class'.

The assignment contains two parts.

Part 1 requires students to create an income statement and balance sheet from a series of accounting transactions. They are required to complete a firm's accounting cycle for a single period. Having created the financial statement, students are asked to provide a basic ratio analysis on the resultant financial statement and briefly comment on the ratios.

Part 2 requires students to create a budget from data contained within the question. Having created the budget, students are asked to provide an assessment of the budget and briefly comment on the value of the budget with regard to improving organisational decision making.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"07bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"07bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"07bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0fbc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"97bc4c66db617050be4672f5f3961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Online Quiz 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Multiple-choice questions

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 and 2.

It is primarily qualitative (limited calculations) and seeks to assess participants' understanding of the meaning of basic accounting terminology, the components of primary financial statements and their knowledge of the accounting equation.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 15 multiple-choice questions. The duration of the quiz is 30 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the quiz at 7.45pm, in which case you would finish at 8.15pm).

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6210.

The course provides a broad introduction to all aspects of the accounting function. The language of accounting and financial management is exacting. Our aim is to increase your familiarity with key components of this language and allow you to more effectively communicate with all organisational stakeholders. Users of accounting information may be typically classified as either external users (such as investors) or internal users (such as operational managers). Different users have different information needs. This course deals with the needs of these two main user groups and how the senior management of organisations can more effectively use accounting data to connect with them.

The subject will explore accounting techniques and terminology to equip students with sufficient conceptual and practical skills to make them, and any professional who may advise them, confident in their ability to understand and communicate complex financial strategies.

This subject also examines the design and operation of accounting systems. As a result, the course integrates ideas and concepts from accounting with a range of other disciplines and reveals how the effective use of financial information provided by such systems can improve organisational decision-making.

It is assumed that students have little prior knowledge of accounting and financial management.
contentlets.title: Accounting and Financial Management

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM6234 - Data Analytics and Decision-making","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9234.


Evidence-based decision-making, supported by a data-driven culture, is critical to the success of organisations. It is essential that professionals can define problems clearly and systematically, know what techniques can be applied in order to solve these problems, and communicate the results concisely and effectively. This course helps students to frame business problems in a quantitative matter and learn how data collection and experimentation can help provide management insights. As the second step, students will learn how to solve problems through predictive models. This requires a basic understanding of statistics and therefore students will study the basics of regression provided by the Harvard Quantitative Methods online course during the first five weeks. This will help improve students’ data literacy in order to communicate more effectively with data scientists, as well as contribute to the democratisation of data within their business. Finally, students will learn the basics of using Tableau, one of the leading Data Analytics and Visualisation tools in the field. Through data storytelling, students will learn to communicate data more effectively and improve their ability to simplify problems and facilitate decision-making. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e339d271bde3c50d5fb0fabdc4bcbf6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Data-driven decision-making: Data storytelling with Tableau","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assessment, students will use the framework for quantitative decision making to frame a problem, solve it analytically and communicate their findings and recommendations. Students will work in groups, and use all skills learned in Tableau in order to analyse their data and create a data story.

It is important that students' findings and recommendations are tailored towards a clear audience that might consist of clients, business leaders or policy makers – depending on students' goals and analysis.

Students will cover the Harvard material on regression as they take the first five units of the course. This will ensure they have the necessary knowledge to work with the course material on predictive modelling.

This task is considered formative and has been set with a recommended 65% 'pass' mark (i.e. a UNSW-level 'credit' mark) due to its importance and its use of multiple-choice questions.

Online-forum participation and case-study preparation. 

Active participation in the online class will provide students with the best foundation to learn in Data Analytics & Decision-making. Each week students will engage in online discussion about the application of insights, case studies and other material.

When working through case studies, students may be required to write a half-page summary of the case  as part of their participation requirements. The practice of summarising extensive overviews of information will enrich both students' ability to make strong arguments and the quality of the discussion forum. 

Students will also engage by providing Facts of the Week. There are many examples of applications of Data Analytics & Decision-making in commercial companies, NGOs and public policies that can be found online and all around us. This activity is an opportunity to recognise and find examples of how Data Analytics & Decision-making is applied in practice.

The facilitator will provide a schedule allocating students per week (Weeks 2-9) and will give more details about the requirements of this assessment in the Moodle class site. Students will be required to do this task only once as a discussion lead, but are free to provide facts of the week as often as they like.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9234.

Evidence-based decision-making, supported by a data-driven culture, is critical to the success of organisations. It is essential that professionals can define problems clearly and systematically, know what techniques can be applied in order to solve these problems, and communicate the results concisely and effectively. This course helps students to frame business problems in a quantitative matter and learn how data collection and experimentation can help provide management insights. As the second step, students will learn how to solve problems through predictive models. This requires a basic understanding of statistics and therefore students will study the basics of regression provided by the Harvard Quantitative Methods online course during the first five weeks. This will help improve students’ data literacy in order to communicate more effectively with data scientists, as well as contribute to the democratisation of data within their business. Finally, students will learn the basics of using Tableau, one of the leading Data Analytics and Visualisation tools in the field. Through data storytelling, students will learn to communicate data more effectively and improve their ability to simplify problems and facilitate decision-making.
contentlets.title: Data Analytics and Decision-making

Management","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6251.


At the core of every successful business model are the organisation’s value propositions. Leaders of contemporary organisations must understand how the organisation creates and manages value propositions based on understanding the wants and needs of key stakeholders. This list of stakeholders includes existing and potential customers (a.k.a. clients or funding bodies), employees, suppliers, partners or collaborators, investors, government/regulators, and communities. Doing this successfully means that through appreciating the impacts of complex conditions in the external environment, contemporary leaders are better able to create, communicate, deliver, and sustain value for their stakeholders, and capture value for the organisation. This requires an understanding of the core processes and practices of marketing management.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6251.

At the core of every successful business model are the organisation’s value propositions. Leaders of contemporary organisations must understand how the organisation creates and manages value propositions based on understanding the wants and needs of key stakeholders. This list of stakeholders includes existing and potential customers (a.k.a. clients or funding bodies), employees, suppliers, partners or collaborators, investors, government/regulators, and communities. Doing this successfully means that through appreciating the impacts of complex conditions in the external environment, contemporary leaders are better able to create, communicate, deliver, and sustain value for their stakeholders, and capture value for the organisation. This requires an understanding of the core processes and practices of marketing management.
contentlets.title: Marketing Management

Organisations","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6275.


This course explores the issues you face in managing people, groups and organisations. We ask such questions as:


  • What is my role as a manager and a leader?
  • What motivates people at work?
  • How does my group function, and how can it be more effective?
  • What impact does the structure and culture of my organisation have on our performance?

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6275.

This course explores the issues you face in managing people, groups and organisations. We ask such questions as:

  • What is my role as a manager and a leader?
  • What motivates people at work?
  • How does my group function, and how can it be more effective?
  • What impact does the structure and culture of my organisation have on our performance?
contentlets.title: Managing People and Organisations

In examining value, you will be introduced to the three basic ideas in finance:

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9101 - Project Management","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9101.


Project [noun] a piece of planned work or an activity that is finished over a period of time and intended to achieve a particular purpose (Cambridge English Dictionary, n.d.).


Projects are the means by which organisations implement their strategy.


They are ubiquitous across industry and domain: as a manager or leader in any modern organisation, you will be directly involved in projects - as a team member, a project or program manager, a subject-matter expert, a sponsor or owner, or as a client.


As your career progresses, you can expect to face increasingly complex challenges in dealing with larger projects, more demanding stakeholders, tighter constraints on human, financial and other resources, and a rapidly changing environment. You will be expected to improve the efficiency, productivity and performance of your teams, and determine which projects and initiatives will best deliver the organisation's mandate.


An increasing number of organisations are 'projectising' routine work to gain the benefits of project management. At the same time, agile and flexible work practices are blurring the distinction between project and operational work. At the other end of the scale, the increasing number of complex projects and megaprojects require more rigorous approaches to both managing and governing an organisation's project portfolio.


This course provides an introduction to the rapidly growing world of project, program and portfolio management (PPPM or 3PM). The 12 Units address various themes around managing projects in modern organisations, and take you through key processes that contribute to the successful delivery of a project. We start with an introduction to project management, and follow with requisite project-management methodologies and skills, management of the stakeholders and individuals assigned to project teams, project planning and project communications, project execution and control, and project closure. Woven through each Unit are the attributes of responsible leadership underpinning sustainable future organisations.


However, we can only scratch the surface of what is an ever-expanding field of study. Every project is, by definition, unique: there is no one-size-fits-all approach to project management. While we present a simple framework for project management, and assignments and a simulation against which to apply it, our real objective is to challenge your thinking about project management, and how it can be exploited to deliver value to your organisations and stakeholders.


Whether you contribute to projects, manage multiple small projects or a single large one, or are responsible for a project portfolio or a team of project managers, we trust you will find this course challenges you and equips you to improve your own and your organisation's project delivery capabilities.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1769dacddbadf810be4672f5f396194d","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Simulation Reflection Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

During the first few weeks of the term, you will manage several simulated projects through Harvard’s Project Management Simulation: Scope, Resources, Schedule. The simulation provides several different scenarios, each of which enables you to explore and reflect on different facets of project delivery, and the interdependence of various ‘levers’.

\n\n

On completion of each simulation, you should reflect on what you attempted, and what you have learned as a result. These reflections can then be compiled into a report addressing how each of the following factors impact on project outcomes:

\n\n
  • the targeted scope, schedule and budget
  • the composition of the project team (team size, skill level, team stability, degree of outsourcing)
  • the approach taken to delivering the project (team engagement and training, types of reporting, use of prototyping, manager expectations, project decision-making, etc.) and how this helps to moderate the impact of uncertainty on projects.
\n\n

Your conclusions should be supported by a) examples from your simulated project runs, and b) evidence from the study material.

\n\n

At the end of Week 2, the Course Coordinator will present a webinar to debrief the simulation outcomes. This will provide useful input to the assignment. A recording will be made available for students unable to attend the webinar live.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  2. Methodology - a description of how you approached the assignment, captured the data and used it to generate the insights identified in the next section.
  3. Analysis and insights - drawing on the concepts covered in Units 1–3 and the results of your simulated runs, critically assess the interdependencies between a project’s scope, resourcing and schedule constraints, and how each of these could impact on team performance. Illustrate your conclusions with references to specific simulated projects you undertook.
  4. Recommendations - the final section contains your recommendations for managing projects under various conditions. What advice would you give project managers who face considerable uncertainty or unrealistic expectations?
  5. Supporting data (appendix) - include a list of your simulated project runs and your objective for each attempt. What were you hoping to learn from it, and what insights did you gain?
\n\n

Details of how to write and structure reports are available in the online AGSM Learning Toolkit available in Moodle.

TC1.1: The project management plan

\n\n

A document of no more than 2-5 pages, outlining how you intend to deliver the project. It will include:

\n\n
  1. a statement outlining the project objective and approach taken
  2. a team contract and communications management plan, addressing how the team will work together to deliver the output
  3. the baselined schedule and resource plan
  4. a risk assessment and risk treatment plan
  5. an overview of how the project will be monitored and controlled.
\n\n

Unit 2 includes a template that can be used as a foundation for this plan. This plan must be uploaded to the designated folder by the designated date.

\n\n

TC1.2: The project status reports

\n\n

A project status report (PSR) will be delivered at the end of Week 8 and Week 10. Each status report should be one to two pages in length, and address project progress, issues and risks. A sample template will be provided in Unit 2, while Unit 9 focuses on progress reporting.

\n\n

TC2.1: The report

\n\n

The product your team is producing is a report outlining your assessment of the issues affecting a troubled project (‘the brief’). You will analyse the case, identify the underlying causes, and provide recommendations on how the client should proceed. The written report must not exceed 20 pages, including all appendices and references.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Executive Summary - a short summary of the key issues and recommendations addressed in the report. Unlike an abstract, the Executive Summary should be able to stand on its own.
  2. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  3. Recommendations - lists the recommendations you believe the client should undertake in order to address the project. These should flow directly from the analysis, and be presented in concise, unambiguous terms. It is useful to differentiate between short term and longer-term actions, and to have recommendations prioritised by importance.
  4. Analysis and findings - the analysis you undertook to come to the set of recommendations you suggested.
  5. Supporting data - this section provides any additional data required to support the analysis and findings. This includes materials referenced, stakeholders interviewed, and any data analysis that may have been undertaken. A copy of the presentation material should also be included.
\n\n

Note that the report must be available to the Facilitator prior to the team presentation (TC2.2).

\n\n

TC2.2: The presentation

\n\n

Your team will have 20 minutes to deliver your findings and recommendations to the ‘client’ (the Facilitator). You should allow an additional 5-10 minutes for questions and discussion.

\n\n

This presentation needs to be scheduled with your Facilitator to be delivered either in person, or via videoconference. It is up to each team to negotiate a suitable time frame and technology with their Facilitator.

\n\n

The written report must be submitted to the Facilitator via Turnitin prior to the start of the presentation.

The ‘newshound’ activity is an area in which you can apply your study material to items in the news. These marks will be assigned based on your contribution to and discussion of project-management-related stories currently in the news, and which relate to material being studied at that time. Further information on this activity and the assessment criteria for it will be advised in class or online in the discussion forums.

In addition, your Facilitator will set specific interactive tasks and activities for you to complete as part of this assessment, including review quizzes, practical application of concepts, calculations and/or simulation activities.

Assignment 2 is the practical application of project-management skills, and comprises individual and team components.

\n\n

Individual component (25%)

\n\n
  • IC1 Peer evaluation
  • IC2 Reflective report
\n\n

Team component (30%)

\n\n
  • TC1. Process\n\t
    • TC1.1 Planning\n\t\t
      • Team contract
      • baseline plan
      • Risk register
      \n\t\t
    • TC1.2 Reporting\n\t\t
      • TC2.1 PSR1

      \n\t\t
    \n\n\t

    The brief

    \n\n\t

    Your team has been approached to review a troubled project. You have been asked to assess the project, identify the issues and their underlying causes, and provide a set of recommendations on how the client should proceed. They have requested a report outlining the pertinent issues and recommendations. They expect you to present your findings to the project board and to respond to any questions board members may have.

    \n\n\t

    You will be briefed on the project in Week 4, and are expected to deliver your written report in Week 12 (the presentation will take place in Week 12 or Week 13, by arrangement with your facilitator). The timeline for deliverables is indicated below.

    \n\n\t

    Weeks 4 - 6: Initiate and plan

    \n\n\t
    • Project Management Plan: TC1.1
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 7 -12: Implement 

    \n\n\t
    • Report: TC2.1
    • Presentation: TC2.2
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 12 - 13: Close

    \n\n\t
    • Peer Review: IC1
    • Reflective Report: IC2
    \n\t
\n\n

Individual Component:

\n\n

This is an individual exercise and consists of two components:

\n\n
  • a peer evaluation
  • a final reflective report (1,000 - 1,500 words) reviewing the contribution of each team member and the effectiveness of the team process. The report will also consider key insights gained as a result of the project (group assignment).
\n\n

IC1: Peer evaluation

\n\n

A vital and compulsory component of the second assignment is the peer evaluation that each student will complete. These evaluations may influence the final marks attained for the team component of the assignment; this process is explained below.

\n\n

The result of the peer evaluation should be a table such as the one indicated below, which must be attached to the final report as an appendix. The content of this Appendix does not count towards the report’s word limit.

\n\n

IC2: The reflective report

\n\n

The final component of the assignment is the individual reflective report, which each student needs to submit through Turnitin by the designated date. This report provides you with an opportunity to reflect on how you and your team performed.

\n\n

You will assess:

\n\n
  1. your own contribution to the overall success of the project, including where you felt you performed well or could have improved
  2. the contribution of each team member to the success of your project, including where you felt they demonstrated particular strength or deficiency
  3. the effectiveness of the process your team followed to deliver the outcome
  4. the lessons or insights you gained from the group assignment.
\n\n

The report does not require an executive summary, table of contents or reference list (unless sources are cited). It may be written in the first person.

\n\n

The report must include the peer-evaluation table outlined above, which supports the comments you make related to your own performance and that of your team members. You are also required to indicate how the constructive feedback was delivered to each of the team members (e.g. as part of a team close-out meeting, in a one-on-one conversation, or via email).

\n\n

Guidelines on requesting and providing constructive feedback are included in Unit 10 of the course material.

During the first few weeks of the term, you will manage several simulated projects through Harvard’s Project Management Simulation: Scope, Resources, Schedule. The simulation provides several different scenarios, each of which enables you to explore and reflect on different facets of project delivery, and the interdependence of various ‘levers’.

\n\n

On completion of each simulation, you should reflect on what you attempted, and what you have learned as a result. These reflections can then be compiled into a report addressing how each of the following factors impact on project outcomes:

\n\n
  • the targeted scope, schedule and budget
  • the composition of the project team (team size, skill level, team stability, degree of outsourcing)
  • the approach taken to delivering the project (team engagement and training, types of reporting, use of prototyping, manager expectations, project decision-making, etc.) and how this helps to moderate the impact of uncertainty on projects.
\n\n

Your conclusions should be supported by a) examples from your simulated project runs, and b) evidence from the study material.

\n\n

At the end of Week 2, the Course Coordinator will present a webinar to debrief the simulation outcomes. This will provide useful input to the assignment. A recording will be made available for students unable to attend the webinar live.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  2. Methodology - a description of how you approached the assignment, captured the data and used it to generate the insights identified in the next section.
  3. Analysis and insights - drawing on the concepts covered in Units 1–3 and the results of your simulated runs, critically assess the interdependencies between a project’s scope, resourcing and schedule constraints, and how each of these could impact on team performance. Illustrate your conclusions with references to specific simulated projects you undertook.
  4. Recommendations - the final section contains your recommendations for managing projects under various conditions. What advice would you give project managers who face considerable uncertainty or unrealistic expectations?
  5. Supporting data (appendix) - include a list of your simulated project runs and your objective for each attempt. What were you hoping to learn from it, and what insights did you gain?
\n\n

Details of how to write and structure reports are available in the online AGSM Learning Toolkit available in Moodle.

TC1.1: The project management plan

\n\n

A document of no more than 2-5 pages, outlining how you intend to deliver the project. It will include:

\n\n
  1. a statement outlining the project objective and approach taken
  2. a team contract and communications management plan, addressing how the team will work together to deliver the output
  3. the baselined schedule and resource plan
  4. a risk assessment and risk treatment plan
  5. an overview of how the project will be monitored and controlled.
\n\n

Unit 2 includes a template that can be used as a foundation for this plan. This plan must be uploaded to the designated folder by the designated date.

\n\n

TC1.2: The project status reports

\n\n

A project status report (PSR) will be delivered at the end of Week 8 and Week 10. Each status report should be one to two pages in length, and address project progress, issues and risks. A sample template will be provided in Unit 2, while Unit 9 focuses on progress reporting.

\n\n

TC2.1: The report

\n\n

The product your team is producing is a report outlining your assessment of the issues affecting a troubled project (‘the brief’). You will analyse the case, identify the underlying causes, and provide recommendations on how the client should proceed. The written report must not exceed 20 pages, including all appendices and references.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Executive Summary - a short summary of the key issues and recommendations addressed in the report. Unlike an abstract, the Executive Summary should be able to stand on its own.
  2. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  3. Recommendations - lists the recommendations you believe the client should undertake in order to address the project. These should flow directly from the analysis, and be presented in concise, unambiguous terms. It is useful to differentiate between short term and longer-term actions, and to have recommendations prioritised by importance.
  4. Analysis and findings - the analysis you undertook to come to the set of recommendations you suggested.
  5. Supporting data - this section provides any additional data required to support the analysis and findings. This includes materials referenced, stakeholders interviewed, and any data analysis that may have been undertaken. A copy of the presentation material should also be included.
\n\n

Note that the report must be available to the Facilitator prior to the team presentation (TC2.2).

\n\n

TC2.2: The presentation

\n\n

Your team will have 20 minutes to deliver your findings and recommendations to the ‘client’ (the Facilitator). You should allow an additional 5-10 minutes for questions and discussion.

\n\n

This presentation needs to be scheduled with your Facilitator to be delivered either in person, or via videoconference. It is up to each team to negotiate a suitable time frame and technology with their Facilitator.

\n\n

The written report must be submitted to the Facilitator via Turnitin prior to the start of the presentation.

During the first few weeks of the term, you will manage several simulated projects through Harvard’s Project Management Simulation: Scope, Resources, Schedule. The simulation provides several different scenarios, each of which enables you to explore and reflect on different facets of project delivery, and the interdependence of various ‘levers’.

\n\n

On completion of each simulation, you should reflect on what you attempted, and what you have learned as a result. These reflections can then be compiled into a report addressing how each of the following factors impact on project outcomes:

\n\n
  • the targeted scope, schedule and budget
  • the composition of the project team (team size, skill level, team stability, degree of outsourcing)
  • the approach taken to delivering the project (team engagement and training, types of reporting, use of prototyping, manager expectations, project decision-making, etc.) and how this helps to moderate the impact of uncertainty on projects.
\n\n

Your conclusions should be supported by a) examples from your simulated project runs, and b) evidence from the study material.

\n\n

At the end of Week 2, the Course Coordinator will present a webinar to debrief the simulation outcomes. This will provide useful input to the assignment. A recording will be made available for students unable to attend the webinar live.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  2. Methodology - a description of how you approached the assignment, captured the data and used it to generate the insights identified in the next section.
  3. Analysis and insights - drawing on the concepts covered in Units 1–3 and the results of your simulated runs, critically assess the interdependencies between a project’s scope, resourcing and schedule constraints, and how each of these could impact on team performance. Illustrate your conclusions with references to specific simulated projects you undertook.
  4. Recommendations - the final section contains your recommendations for managing projects under various conditions. What advice would you give project managers who face considerable uncertainty or unrealistic expectations?
  5. Supporting data (appendix) - include a list of your simulated project runs and your objective for each attempt. What were you hoping to learn from it, and what insights did you gain?
\n\n

Details of how to write and structure reports are available in the online AGSM Learning Toolkit available in Moodle.

TC1.1: The project management plan

\n\n

A document of no more than 2-5 pages, outlining how you intend to deliver the project. It will include:

\n\n
  1. a statement outlining the project objective and approach taken
  2. a team contract and communications management plan, addressing how the team will work together to deliver the output
  3. the baselined schedule and resource plan
  4. a risk assessment and risk treatment plan
  5. an overview of how the project will be monitored and controlled.
\n\n

Unit 2 includes a template that can be used as a foundation for this plan. This plan must be uploaded to the designated folder by the designated date.

\n\n

TC1.2: The project status reports

\n\n

A project status report (PSR) will be delivered at the end of Week 8 and Week 10. Each status report should be one to two pages in length, and address project progress, issues and risks. A sample template will be provided in Unit 2, while Unit 9 focuses on progress reporting.

\n\n

TC2.1: The report

\n\n

The product your team is producing is a report outlining your assessment of the issues affecting a troubled project (‘the brief’). You will analyse the case, identify the underlying causes, and provide recommendations on how the client should proceed. The written report must not exceed 20 pages, including all appendices and references.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Executive Summary - a short summary of the key issues and recommendations addressed in the report. Unlike an abstract, the Executive Summary should be able to stand on its own.
  2. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  3. Recommendations - lists the recommendations you believe the client should undertake in order to address the project. These should flow directly from the analysis, and be presented in concise, unambiguous terms. It is useful to differentiate between short term and longer-term actions, and to have recommendations prioritised by importance.
  4. Analysis and findings - the analysis you undertook to come to the set of recommendations you suggested.
  5. Supporting data - this section provides any additional data required to support the analysis and findings. This includes materials referenced, stakeholders interviewed, and any data analysis that may have been undertaken. A copy of the presentation material should also be included.
\n\n

Note that the report must be available to the Facilitator prior to the team presentation (TC2.2).

\n\n

TC2.2: The presentation

\n\n

Your team will have 20 minutes to deliver your findings and recommendations to the ‘client’ (the Facilitator). You should allow an additional 5-10 minutes for questions and discussion.

\n\n

This presentation needs to be scheduled with your Facilitator to be delivered either in person, or via videoconference. It is up to each team to negotiate a suitable time frame and technology with their Facilitator.

\n\n

The written report must be submitted to the Facilitator via Turnitin prior to the start of the presentation.

Assignment 2 is the practical application of project-management skills, and comprises individual and team components.

\n\n

Individual component (25%)

\n\n
  • IC1 Peer evaluation
  • IC2 Reflective report
\n\n

Team component (30%)

\n\n
  • TC1. Process\n\t
    • TC1.1 Planning\n\t\t
      • Team contract
      • baseline plan
      • Risk register
      \n\t\t
    • TC1.2 Reporting\n\t\t
      • TC2.1 PSR1
      • TC2.2 PSR2
      \n\t\t
    \n\n\t

    The brief

    \n\n\t

    Your team has been approached to review a troubled project. You have been asked to assess the project, identify the issues and their underlying causes, and provide a set of recommendations on how the client should proceed. They have requested a report outlining the pertinent issues and recommendations. They expect you to present your findings to the project board and to respond to any questions board members may have.

    \n\n\t

    You will be briefed on the project in Week 4, and are expected to deliver your written report in Week 12 (the presentation will take place in Week 12 or Week 13, by arrangement with your facilitator). The timeline for deliverables is indicated below.

    \n\n\t

    Weeks 4 - 6: Initiate and plan

    \n\n\t
    • Project Management Plan: TC1.1
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 7 -12: Implement 

    \n\n\t
    • Report: TC2.1
    • Presentation: TC2.2
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 12 - 13: Close

    \n\n\t
    • Peer Review: IC1
    • Reflective Report: IC2
    \n\t
\n\n

Individual Component:

\n\n

This is an individual exercise and consists of two components:

\n\n
  • a peer evaluation
  • a final reflective report (1,000 - 1,500 words) reviewing the contribution of each team member and the effectiveness of the team process. The report will also consider key insights gained as a result of the project (group assignment).
\n\n

IC1: Peer evaluation

\n\n

A vital and compulsory component of the second assignment is the peer evaluation that each student will complete. These evaluations may influence the final marks attained for the team component of the assignment; this process is explained below.

\n\n

The result of the peer evaluation should be a table such as the one indicated below, which must be attached to the final report as an appendix. The content of this Appendix does not count towards the report’s word limit.

\n\n

IC2: The reflective report

\n\n

The final component of the assignment is the individual reflective report, which each student needs to submit through Turnitin by the designated date. This report provides you with an opportunity to reflect on how you and your team performed.

\n\n

You will assess:

\n\n
  1. your own contribution to the overall success of the project, including where you felt you performed well or could have improved
  2. the contribution of each team member to the success of your project, including where you felt they demonstrated particular strength or deficiency
  3. the effectiveness of the process your team followed to deliver the outcome
  4. the lessons or insights you gained from the group assignment.
\n\n

The report does not require an executive summary, table of contents or reference list (unless sources are cited). It may be written in the first person.

\n\n

The report must include the peer-evaluation table outlined above, which supports the comments you make related to your own performance and that of your team members. You are also required to indicate how the constructive feedback was delivered to each of the team members (e.g. as part of a team close-out meeting, in a one-on-one conversation, or via email).

\n\n

Guidelines on requesting and providing constructive feedback are included in Unit 10 of the course material.

During the first few weeks of the term, you will manage several simulated projects through Harvard’s Project Management Simulation: Scope, Resources, Schedule. The simulation provides several different scenarios, each of which enables you to explore and reflect on different facets of project delivery, and the interdependence of various ‘levers’.

\n\n

On completion of each simulation, you should reflect on what you attempted, and what you have learned as a result. These reflections can then be compiled into a report addressing how each of the following factors impact on project outcomes:

\n\n
  • the targeted scope, schedule and budget
  • the composition of the project team (team size, skill level, team stability, degree of outsourcing)
  • the approach taken to delivering the project (team engagement and training, types of reporting, use of prototyping, manager expectations, project decision-making, etc.) and how this helps to moderate the impact of uncertainty on projects.
\n\n

Your conclusions should be supported by a) examples from your simulated project runs, and b) evidence from the study material.

\n\n

At the end of Week 2, the Course Coordinator will present a webinar to debrief the simulation outcomes. This will provide useful input to the assignment. A recording will be made available for students unable to attend the webinar live.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  2. Methodology - a description of how you approached the assignment, captured the data and used it to generate the insights identified in the next section.
  3. Analysis and insights - drawing on the concepts covered in Units 1–3 and the results of your simulated runs, critically assess the interdependencies between a project’s scope, resourcing and schedule constraints, and how each of these could impact on team performance. Illustrate your conclusions with references to specific simulated projects you undertook.
  4. Recommendations - the final section contains your recommendations for managing projects under various conditions. What advice would you give project managers who face considerable uncertainty or unrealistic expectations?
  5. Supporting data (appendix) - include a list of your simulated project runs and your objective for each attempt. What were you hoping to learn from it, and what insights did you gain?
\n\n

Details of how to write and structure reports are available in the online AGSM Learning Toolkit available in Moodle.

TC1.1: The project management plan

\n\n

A document of no more than 2-5 pages, outlining how you intend to deliver the project. It will include:

\n\n
  1. a statement outlining the project objective and approach taken
  2. a team contract and communications management plan, addressing how the team will work together to deliver the output
  3. the baselined schedule and resource plan
  4. a risk assessment and risk treatment plan
  5. an overview of how the project will be monitored and controlled.
\n\n

Unit 2 includes a template that can be used as a foundation for this plan. This plan must be uploaded to the designated folder by the designated date.

\n\n

TC1.2: The project status reports

\n\n

A project status report (PSR) will be delivered at the end of Week 8 and Week 10. Each status report should be one to two pages in length, and address project progress, issues and risks. A sample template will be provided in Unit 2, while Unit 9 focuses on progress reporting.

\n\n

TC2.1: The report

\n\n

The product your team is producing is a report outlining your assessment of the issues affecting a troubled project (‘the brief’). You will analyse the case, identify the underlying causes, and provide recommendations on how the client should proceed. The written report must not exceed 20 pages, including all appendices and references.

\n\n

The report should contain the following:

\n\n
  1. Executive Summary - a short summary of the key issues and recommendations addressed in the report. Unlike an abstract, the Executive Summary should be able to stand on its own.
  2. Introduction and conclusion - a short introduction that explains the purpose and context of the report. The conclusion provides the final statements to bring all the sections of the report together.
  3. Recommendations - lists the recommendations you believe the client should undertake in order to address the project. These should flow directly from the analysis, and be presented in concise, unambiguous terms. It is useful to differentiate between short term and longer-term actions, and to have recommendations prioritised by importance.
  4. Analysis and findings - the analysis you undertook to come to the set of recommendations you suggested.
  5. Supporting data - this section provides any additional data required to support the analysis and findings. This includes materials referenced, stakeholders interviewed, and any data analysis that may have been undertaken. A copy of the presentation material should also be included.
\n\n

Note that the report must be available to the Facilitator prior to the team presentation (TC2.2).

\n\n

TC2.2: The presentation

\n\n

Your team will have 20 minutes to deliver your findings and recommendations to the ‘client’ (the Facilitator). You should allow an additional 5-10 minutes for questions and discussion.

\n\n

This presentation needs to be scheduled with your Facilitator to be delivered either in person, or via videoconference. It is up to each team to negotiate a suitable time frame and technology with their Facilitator.

\n\n

The written report must be submitted to the Facilitator via Turnitin prior to the start of the presentation.

Assignment 2 is the practical application of project-management skills, and comprises individual and team components.

\n\n

Individual component (25%)

\n\n
  • IC1 Peer evaluation
  • IC2 Reflective report
\n\n

Team component (30%)

\n\n
  • TC1. Process\n\t
    • TC1.1 Planning\n\t\t
      • Team contract
      • baseline plan
      • Risk register
      \n\t\t
    • TC1.2 Reporting\n\t\t
      • TC2.1 PSR1
      • TC2.2 PSR2
      \n\t\t
    \n\n\t

    The brief

    \n\n\t

    Your team has been approached to review a troubled project. You have been asked to assess the project, identify the issues and their underlying causes, and provide a set of recommendations on how the client should proceed. They have requested a report outlining the pertinent issues and recommendations. They expect you to present your findings to the project board and to respond to any questions board members may have.

    \n\n\t

    You will be briefed on the project in Week 4, and are expected to deliver your written report in Week 12 (the presentation will take place in Week 12 or Week 13, by arrangement with your facilitator). The timeline for deliverables is indicated below.

    \n\n\t

    Weeks 4 - 6: Initiate and plan

    \n\n\t
    • Project Management Plan: TC1.1
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 7 -12: Implement 

    \n\n\t
    • Report: TC2.1
    • Presentation: TC2.2
    \n\n\t

    Weeks 12 - 13: Close

    \n\n\t
    • Peer Review: IC1
    • Reflective Report: IC2
    \n\t
\n\n

Individual Component:

\n\n

This is an individual exercise and consists of two components:

\n\n
  • a peer evaluation
  • a final reflective report (1,000 - 1,500 words) reviewing the contribution of each team member and the effectiveness of the team process. The report will also consider key insights gained as a result of the project (group assignment).
\n\n

IC1: Peer evaluation

\n\n

A vital and compulsory component of the second assignment is the peer evaluation that each student will complete. These evaluations may influence the final marks attained for the team component of the assignment; this process is explained below.

\n\n

The result of the peer evaluation should be a table such as the one indicated below, which must be attached to the final report as an appendix. The content of this Appendix does not count towards the report’s word limit.

\n\n

IC2: The reflective report

\n\n

The final component of the assignment is the individual reflective report, which each student needs to submit through Turnitin by the designated date. This report provides you with an opportunity to reflect on how you and your team performed.

\n\n

You will assess:

\n\n
  1. your own contribution to the overall success of the project, including where you felt you performed well or could have improved
  2. the contribution of each team member to the success of your project, including where you felt they demonstrated particular strength or deficiency
  3. the effectiveness of the process your team followed to deliver the outcome
  4. the lessons or insights you gained from the group assignment.
\n\n

The report does not require an executive summary, table of contents or reference list (unless sources are cited). It may be written in the first person.

\n\n

The report must include the peer-evaluation table outlined above, which supports the comments you make related to your own performance and that of your team members. You are also required to indicate how the constructive feedback was delivered to each of the team members (e.g. as part of a team close-out meeting, in a one-on-one conversation, or via email).

\n\n

Guidelines on requesting and providing constructive feedback are included in Unit 10 of the course material.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9101.

Project [noun] a piece of planned work or an activity that is finished over a period of time and intended to achieve a particular purpose (Cambridge English Dictionary, n.d.).

Projects are the means by which organisations implement their strategy.

They are ubiquitous across industry and domain: as a manager or leader in any modern organisation, you will be directly involved in projects - as a team member, a project or program manager, a subject-matter expert, a sponsor or owner, or as a client.

As your career progresses, you can expect to face increasingly complex challenges in dealing with larger projects, more demanding stakeholders, tighter constraints on human, financial and other resources, and a rapidly changing environment. You will be expected to improve the efficiency, productivity and performance of your teams, and determine which projects and initiatives will best deliver the organisation's mandate.

An increasing number of organisations are 'projectising' routine work to gain the benefits of project management. At the same time, agile and flexible work practices are blurring the distinction between project and operational work. At the other end of the scale, the increasing number of complex projects and megaprojects require more rigorous approaches to both managing and governing an organisation's project portfolio.

This course provides an introduction to the rapidly growing world of project, program and portfolio management (PPPM or 3PM). The 12 Units address various themes around managing projects in modern organisations, and take you through key processes that contribute to the successful delivery of a project. We start with an introduction to project management, and follow with requisite project-management methodologies and skills, management of the stakeholders and individuals assigned to project teams, project planning and project communications, project execution and control, and project closure. Woven through each Unit are the attributes of responsible leadership underpinning sustainable future organisations.

However, we can only scratch the surface of what is an ever-expanding field of study. Every project is, by definition, unique: there is no one-size-fits-all approach to project management. While we present a simple framework for project management, and assignments and a simulation against which to apply it, our real objective is to challenge your thinking about project management, and how it can be exploited to deliver value to your organisations and stakeholders.

Whether you contribute to projects, manage multiple small projects or a single large one, or are responsible for a project portfolio or a team of project managers, we trust you will find this course challenges you and equips you to improve your own and your organisation's project delivery capabilities.
contentlets.title: Project Management

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9103.


Business Management for a Sustainable Environment provides an overview of the range of environment issues facing our community, and the responsibilities of managers in addressing those issues. Via an understanding of the big picture, managers can make sound economic decisions compatible with a commitment to a sustainable environment. The more specific issues and control strategies discussed provide insights into environmental control techniques and methods for handling environmental problems, ranging from legal aspects to quantitative risk assessment.

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9119.


The current global business environment continues to create challenges for organisations and their managers. Managers now face increasing pressure to balance short and long-term needs for economic, social and environmental sustainability. This course examines how organisations and their management can support sustainable organisational strategies. We see how holistic and integrated approaches to people management and stakeholder relations can increase an organisations capability for continuous renewal and long-term viability.

Managing for Organisational Sustainability deals with topics such as organisational capabilities and sustainability, triple bottom line thinking, corporate social responsibility, stakeholder management, alternative performance management systems, organisational learning and change, and managerial competencies for sustainability.


Students who have completed ACCT5985 The Innovative Organisation are not permitted to enrol into this course.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9119.

The current global business environment continues to create challenges for organisations and their managers. Managers now face increasing pressure to balance short and long-term needs for economic, social and environmental sustainability. This course examines how organisations and their management can support sustainable organisational strategies. We see how holistic and integrated approaches to people management and stakeholder relations can increase an organisations capability for continuous renewal and long-term viability.

Managing for Organisational Sustainability deals with topics such as organisational capabilities and sustainability, triple bottom line thinking, corporate social responsibility, stakeholder management, alternative performance management systems, organisational learning and change, and managerial competencies for sustainability.

Students who have completed ACCT5985 The Innovative Organisation are not permitted to enrol into this course.

Practice","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9122.


The performance of an organisation is driven by firm-specific, industry and economic factors. Economics in Management Practice has been developed to give you a deeper understanding of all three of these factors and to provide a rigourous foundation for any further study that you pursue in the area of Strategy.


Microeconomics is the focus of Units 1 to 6 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of both firm-specific and industry factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover the purchase decisions of individual customers and how the features of the industry will influence company profitability. An understanding of microeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict the behaviour of customers, competitors and suppliers. These concepts are foundational to any further study in the area of strategy.


Macroeconomics is the focus of Units 7 to 11 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of the economic factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover that factors that drive economic growth, inflation, employment, interest rates and exchange rates. An understanding of macroeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict how changes in the economy will affect the industry in which they operate

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3432cf45dbe13c10be4672f5f396196e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The Assignment and Presentation involves choosing a real case based on your industry experience, describing that case and then analysing it using the principles covered in Units 1 to 6 of the course. The assessment includes three components: Proposal (due Week 6), Assignment (due Week 10) and a Presentation (due Week 11). The Proposal involves preparing a brief document outlining your group members, your chosen topic and your project plan. The Assignment involves preparing a written case study and solution. The Presentation involves recording a presentation explaining the case study and solution using Microsoft PowerPoint. Each group member must present part of the presentation and you will be marked individually. You will have access to assignments and presentations from previous sessions to help you with this assessment. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Assignment Instructions' and 'Presentation Instructions' documents under the 'Assignment' and 'Presentation' section of the course website

Active participation and interaction with your peers is an important part of this course. If you are enrolled in a face-to-face weekly or intensive class, your participation will be scored based on your attendance and interactions in class. If you are enrolled in a web class, it will be scored based on your interaction in the discussion forums. In order to receive a participation mark, you must upload a clear photograph of yourself onto your profile on Moodle by the end of Week 3 of session. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Participation Instructions' document under the 'Participtation' section of the course website.

For details on Quiz due dates, please refer to the Quiz Instructions document on the course website.

\n\n

This assessment includes a series of weekly online quizzes on the course website that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. There are 10 quizzes in total based on Units 2 to 11 and they are due in Weeks 2 to 11. Each quiz will consist of just 5 questions. Most questions are multiple-choice style but there are also a few calculation questions. You will have 1 hour to complete each quiz from the time you first open it. Your final grade will be based on your best 8 quiz scores. For more detailed information about this assessment including the start and finish times for each quiz, please refer to the 'Quiz Instructions' document under the 'Quizzes' section of the course website.

The final assessment is a take-home exam that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. It will involve using the macroeconomic models covered in Units 7 to 11 of the course to analyse a particular country's economy over a selected period of time. You will receive the exam question to your student email address by the 'Start date' listed above. You must submit your written report on the course website by the 'Due date' listed above. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Exam Instructions' document under the 'Exam' section of the course website.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9122.

The performance of an organisation is driven by firm-specific, industry and economic factors. Economics in Management Practice has been developed to give you a deeper understanding of all three of these factors and to provide a rigourous foundation for any further study that you pursue in the area of Strategy.

Microeconomics is the focus of Units 1 to 6 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of both firm-specific and industry factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover the purchase decisions of individual customers and how the features of the industry will influence company profitability. An understanding of microeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict the behaviour of customers, competitors and suppliers. These concepts are foundational to any further study in the area of strategy.

Macroeconomics is the focus of Units 7 to 11 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of the economic factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover that factors that drive economic growth, inflation, employment, interest rates and exchange rates. An understanding of macroeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict how changes in the economy will affect the industry in which they operate
contentlets.title: Economics in Management Practice

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9124.


Business Law and Technology provides an overview of the legal environment for and the legal regulation of business in Australia. It introduces the Australian legal system, alternative forms of business organisation and the legal framework of business regulation, and examines areas of law of particular relevance to business including business contracts and torts, restrictive trade practices and fair-trading, the protection and exploitation of intellectual property, and technology contracts.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9124.

Business Law and Technology provides an overview of the legal environment for and the legal regulation of business in Australia. It introduces the Australian legal system, alternative forms of business organisation and the legal framework of business regulation, and examines areas of law of particular relevance to business including business contracts and torts, restrictive trade practices and fair-trading, the protection and exploitation of intellectual property, and technology contracts.
contentlets.title: Business Law

NOTE:This course was previously offered as MBAX9126.


This course incorporates both strategic and tactical dimensions of new product and service development. It demonstrates a variety of concepts and modes of thinking about innovation and product development. In more concrete terms, it will provide students with a workable knowledge of a best practice approach to product creation from concept selection through to post-launch monitoring, exposure to a similar approach used by service companies. More generally, it will demonstrate how well service companies perform in new service development compared to manufacturing firms, and highlight the organisation and management practices that are most likely to result in successful new product development.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously offered as MBAX9126.

This course incorporates both strategic and tactical dimensions of new product and service development. It demonstrates a variety of concepts and modes of thinking about innovation and product development. In more concrete terms, it will provide students with a workable knowledge of a best practice approach to product creation from concept selection through to post-launch monitoring, exposure to a similar approach used by service companies. More generally, it will demonstrate how well service companies perform in new service development compared to manufacturing firms, and highlight the organisation and management practices that are most likely to result in successful new product development.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9127 - Supply Chain Management","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9127.


In this course, you will examine the basic concepts and tools of supply chain management within the broader framework of an organisation's overall competitive strategy.
The supply chain, which comprises all aspects of the sourcing of inputs from upstream suppliers, the internal value-adding processes and the distribution of outputs to downstream customers, is central to the overall success of any organisation. Any organisation that does not align its overall corporate strategy and its supply chain strategy will struggle to successfully deliver products and services to the market in a form that customers value.


While it is not necessary for participants to be highly skilled in mathematics to undertake this course, you are expected to be familiar with, or be prepared to acquire, basic knowledge about the following concepts:


  • basic probability and statistics
  • probability distributions and standard deviations (particularly the normal distribution)
  • means and weighted averages
  • basic algebra.

You will be expected to be able to perform some basic algebraic and statistical calculations in this course.


This course offers a broad examination of the key issues involved in the management of supply chains. It places supply chain management in a strategic context and requires a blend of managerial and technological knowledge and skills.


However, the course begins with a guided analysis of the strategic context of the organisation, so it can be taken early in your degree program, before any other strategy courses have been completed.


This course is well suited to a broad range of students? not only those involved in manufacturing industries? as the concepts, processes and methods are readily adaptable to organisations that provide hard or soft product/service combination industries. One full Unit is devoted to service supply chains. There are numerous other references and opportunities to apply the theory to service supply chains in both the Unit notes and the associated textbook.

4: Newshound activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"8","weighting":"15","description":"

n addition to the general participation forum, which links directly to the course topics, the Newshound Activity is an opportunity for us to keep in touch with ‘real-time’ supply chain management stories as they happen. While course notes and textbooks contain great and often timeless theory, thanks to the internet we can explore the globe for relevant supply chain material and bring this to the table for discussion and debate.

\n\n

At the start of our first week, the Class Facilitator will post a Newshound Timetable that provides a slot for each student to post a newshound activity in their nominated week of the session. This ensures that we get an even spread, rather than all Newshounds being posted in Week 1 (or Week 12!)

\n\n

For this activity, each student is to ‘sniff out' a current item in the news that is timely (say, a maximum of 12 months old) and relevant to the particular topic to which you will be assigned. You will then post a link to the item in the Newshound Forum and very briefly discuss the relevance of the item to the topic.

\n\n

You also need to respond to anyone who comments on, or analyses, your Newshound post.
\nNote: To make this activity work, each student is expected to respond to at least one other Newshound post, offering an analysis of the article and the supply chain issues contained within it.

\n\n

In summary, there are three tasks you need to undertake in this activity:

\n\n
  1. post your own Newshound
  2. respond to anyone who comments on your Newshound post
  3. respond to other Newshounds (at least one).
\n\n

A Newshound forum will be provided on the Moodle site and will remain open all session.

\n\n

The Class Facilitator will kick it off with examples in the first few weeks.

Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning. Participation is broadly assessed on your contributions to discussion activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way, we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

\n\n

Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive activities and tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment. These will be clearly linked to each week’s unit materials and topics.

\n\n

You will receive feedback on your forum participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark at the end of the course.
