contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9127.

In this course, you will examine the basic concepts and tools of supply chain management within the broader framework of an organisation's overall competitive strategy.
The supply chain, which comprises all aspects of the sourcing of inputs from upstream suppliers, the internal value-adding processes and the distribution of outputs to downstream customers, is central to the overall success of any organisation. Any organisation that does not align its overall corporate strategy and its supply chain strategy will struggle to successfully deliver products and services to the market in a form that customers value.

While it is not necessary for participants to be highly skilled in mathematics to undertake this course, you are expected to be familiar with, or be prepared to acquire, basic knowledge about the following concepts:

  • basic probability and statistics
  • probability distributions and standard deviations (particularly the normal distribution)
  • means and weighted averages
  • basic algebra.

You will be expected to be able to perform some basic algebraic and statistical calculations in this course.

This course offers a broad examination of the key issues involved in the management of supply chains. It places supply chain management in a strategic context and requires a blend of managerial and technological knowledge and skills.

However, the course begins with a guided analysis of the strategic context of the organisation, so it can be taken early in your degree program, before any other strategy courses have been completed.

This course is well suited to a broad range of students? not only those involved in manufacturing industries? as the concepts, processes and methods are readily adaptable to organisations that provide hard or soft product/service combination industries. One full Unit is devoted to service supply chains. There are numerous other references and opportunities to apply the theory to service supply chains in both the Unit notes and the associated textbook.
contentlets.title: Supply Chain Management

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9129 - Managing Organisational Resources","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9129.


The course aims to provide a performance management framework for managing major types of enterprise resources. A total enterprise perspective is employed, positioning the organisation in its value creation system. The nature of the resources to be managed and their relative importance is examined, as well as the management issues related to and appropriate performance measurement techniques available for assessing each type of resource. An enterprise governance framework is used to guide the process by linking resource management to the performance of strategy, risk management, corporate ethics and ethos, corporate governance structures and processes, and social and environmental responsibility.

contentlets.keywords: mbax,value creation,resource management,enterprise governance,organisational resources,enterprise resources,mbax9129
contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9129.

The course aims to provide a performance management framework for managing major types of enterprise resources. A total enterprise perspective is employed, positioning the organisation in its value creation system. The nature of the resources to be managed and their relative importance is examined, as well as the management issues related to and appropriate performance measurement techniques available for assessing each type of resource. An enterprise governance framework is used to guide the process by linking resource management to the performance of strategy, risk management, corporate ethics and ethos, corporate governance structures and processes, and social and environmental responsibility.
contentlets.title: Managing Organisational Resources

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"AGSM9130","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9130 - Enterprise Risk Management","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9130.


This course considers external and internal drivers that can result in a range of compliance, operational, financial and strategic risks manifesting in organisations. Typical areas of impact examined will include finance, business operations, IT, innovation, crisis response and reputation. An organisation?s culture can impact on the effectiveness of its risk management, which needs to be incorporated into all business planning and decision-making.



The course also examines the role of corporate governance and compliance, introducing students to relevant standards, and suggests methods of developing and implementing appropriate risk-management strategies. That said, the course is not completely focused on compliance, but more on the development of useful risk-management skills, including some of the effective tools available for identifying, assessing and quantifying risk. In addition, a recognition of emerging issues in enterprise risk management will be addressed.



It is the objective of the Course Coordinator that each student completing the course possesses a different view of the concept of risk and how it affects their personal, professional and corporate lives. In addition to a different perspective on risk, each participant should feel they are familiar with the tools and techniques of both identifying and managing risk to reduce its adverse impacts and increase the opportunities risk presents.

Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way, we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.
Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.
In keeping with the university’s 80% attendance guidelines, participation in at least 10 Units of the course is expected.
You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark at the end of the course

Write a report for the senior executive or board of your organisation providing an overview and evaluation of current risk management in the organisation.
Note: If you do not wish to use your own organisation, you may look at UNSW Australia.

Your report should include the following.

  1. An introductory, brief outline of the governance structure of your organisation and where the oversight of risk management and compliance sits.
  2. Three (3) key drivers for risk management in your organisation.
  3. Using a conceptual framework (e.g. AS/NZS 4360, COSO or ISO 31000) describe:
    –  the levels in the organisation where risk management is formally undertaken
    –  the categories of risk that are specifically addressed
    –  the risk-management policies and processes that exist.
  4. Evaluate the current approaches to risk management in your organisation and identify any gaps or areas for improvement.
  5. Make three (3) recommendations for improvement of risk management in your organisation.
  6. Details of appropriate report formats can be found in the AGSM Learning Guide, which is available in Moodle, your online platform.

Note that this assessment requires you to read pages 5 - 31 of the World Economic Forum’s (WEF) Global Risk Report 2019. To find the report see this link.
You are required to write a detailed assessment of the global risk profile, as per the report. The assessment should not be only a summary of the focus and results of the WEF report, but should also include your reflection, analysis and conclusions on the forces that impact the global risk profile and how they are potentially affecting organisations meeting their strategic and operational objectives.

Because this assessment requires you to undertake a series of analysis, there is no prescribed or recommended format for the assessment response – this will depend on the approach you select. You could, for example, take a structured approach, using ISO 31000 or any other analysis from your studies, employing those you feel would be useful in translating the findings of the article into an analysis which would be meaningful to either the organisation you selected for Assessments 1 and 2 or for Australian economic development in general.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"41e4dc6edb617050be4672f5f396191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45e4dc6edb617050be4672f5f396191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO13","cl_id":"c5e410aedb617050be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c5e410aedb617050be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c5e4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"c5e4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"c5e4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"cde410aedb617050be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"cde4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"cde4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cde4dc6edb617050be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a5e410aedb617050be4672f5f3961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Risk management review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Imagine you have been hired as a risk consultant by your organisation. You have been asked to complete a risk review on a significant new strategic program, major project or new initiative that your organisation is planning. Examples could include:

  • a new CEO or director establishing a strategic initiative or cultural change
  • a large-scale re-organisation of a major division or business unit
  • a significant start-up operation or significant project
  • a significant merger or acquisition.

Your report is being written during the planning phase of the project/initiative and has been requested by the CEO to provide assurance that the project/initiative will be conducted within the organisation's degree of risk tolerance. If it is helpful, you may choose to consider a project that has actually been completed in your organisation, or one that is currently underway.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9130.

This course considers external and internal drivers that can result in a range of compliance, operational, financial and strategic risks manifesting in organisations. Typical areas of impact examined will include finance, business operations, IT, innovation, crisis response and reputation. An organisation?s culture can impact on the effectiveness of its risk management, which needs to be incorporated into all business planning and decision-making.


The course also examines the role of corporate governance and compliance, introducing students to relevant standards, and suggests methods of developing and implementing appropriate risk-management strategies. That said, the course is not completely focused on compliance, but more on the development of useful risk-management skills, including some of the effective tools available for identifying, assessing and quantifying risk. In addition, a recognition of emerging issues in enterprise risk management will be addressed.


It is the objective of the Course Coordinator that each student completing the course possesses a different view of the concept of risk and how it affects their personal, professional and corporate lives. In addition to a different perspective on risk, each participant should feel they are familiar with the tools and techniques of both identifying and managing risk to reduce its adverse impacts and increase the opportunities risk presents.
contentlets.title: Enterprise Risk Management

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9132 - Intrapreneurship","description":"

NOTE: This course was identified as MBAX9132 prior to 2022. 


Organisations must increasingly innovate in order to survive and thrive. This course is designed for leaders who intend to apply their entrepreneurial spirit to innovating within established organisations, as well as for managers whose goal is to build and manage innovation processes in the organisation.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961906","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3B: Stage 2 - Write a full paper for your personal plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Your individual project is a full report on your plan for an innovation approach in your organisation.

Use your defined scenario from stage 1 to set the context and intent for your submission. You will need to demonstrate that you have applied different innovation methods and tools in creating an innovation plan applicable for your organisation including demonstrating that you can present an innovation plan that will allow your organisation to create and capture value.

In the appendix, you present the evidence for support in the various stages of your plan underpinned by the human centred design process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e196fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Stage 1 - Define scenario for your personal plan ","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The purpose of this assessment stage is to get you started in planning your individual project for the course. Choose a scenario that best suits your characteristics or goals to form the base for your personal plan.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e196fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: A New Concept Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The Team project will focus on a process used to describe a way of thinking and a set of key outputs and deliverables associated with creative concept exploration and development which is relevant for an intrapreneur. To do this, students will talk to real users; observe people through digital channels; think about real physical, technical, and social constraints; and understand real market pressures. This process will yield innovative experience concepts that have the potential to be buildable, create traction in the marketplace, and forge emotional connections with users. The team project will be used as the basis for the collaborative working sessions. It is very important to emphasise that there will be practical group work between weekly sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e196fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Progress Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Innovation is a team activity and the key behaviours that intrapreneurs need to demonstrate are in relation to collaboration, understanding empathy, iteration, visualisation and questioning. The purpose of a progress report is to allow you to evaluate the relative contribution of the members of your group to the Team project.

You will be required to complete two (2) progress reports on the progress of your group’s activities. Each report is worth 10%.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e196fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f996fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496192e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Active participation and interaction with peers are a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the online class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e196fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e596fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ed96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f996fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961938","links":[]}]},{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1d96fb88dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961905","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3B: Stage 2 - Write a full paper for your personal plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Your individual project is a full report on your plan for an innovation approach in your organisation.

Use your defined scenario from stage 1 to set the context and intent for your submission. You will need to demonstrate that you have applied different innovation methods and tools in creating an innovation plan applicable for your organisation including demonstrating that you can present an innovation plan that will allow your organisation to create and capture value.

In the appendix, you present the evidence for support in the various stages of your plan underpinned by the human centred design process.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was identified as MBAX9132 prior to 2022. 

Organisations must increasingly innovate in order to survive and thrive. This course is designed for leaders who intend to apply their entrepreneurial spirit to innovating within established organisations, as well as for managers whose goal is to build and manage innovation processes in the organisation.
contentlets.title: Intrapreneurship

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9134 - Change Management Research Project","description":"

NOTE:This course was identified as MBAX9134 prior to 2022


The Change Management Research Project (CMRP) is the capstone course for the MBA (Change). It requires reflection on a range of course materials. It is also very applied in that you are required to conduct field research, using a specific research design, and report your experiences. These theoretical and applied themes are blended to maximise your learning.


The main aim of the CMRP is to enable students to synthesise all their learning across the MBA (Change) specialisation courses studied, and to achieve an integrated and common understanding of them. In addition, this capstone course will add significant value to your Master’s degree by building on your knowledge and skills from a range of core disciplines (financial, legal, technological) that may have been developed through your previous courses in the MBA (Change) or prior study and professional experience.


As an AGSM graduate, it is expected that you will have the skills and knowledge to be an effective change-management practitioner at both operational and strategic levels. The change-management specialisation courses in the MBA (Change) have addressed a variety of concepts, issues and principles designed to enhance your change-management capabilities whether in commercial or non-commercial settings. The integration of these courses will be reinforced via this capstone course. It is therefore strongly recommended that it is the final course in your studies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8254bbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961986","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Specialist Online Dialogue","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

The dialogue will focus on ethical, social and environmental responsibility, and social and cultural awareness. These topics are a major component of the MBA (Change) learning outcomes that need to be met at the capstone level, and are vital to effective change-management practice in contemporary society.

Throughout the MBA (Change) specialisation courses we have emphasised that organisations are conceived as open systems, which influence and are influenced by their environment, notably key stakeholders. Organisational sustainability is determined in large part by engagement with these stakeholders. This open-systems view and the stakeholder nexus is of prime importance to change-management practitioners. It raises some significant issues that have been canvassed in your change studies:

·        the ethical responsibility of change-management practitioners

·        the change practitioner’s role in pursuing socially and environmentally responsible business practice

·        the need for social and cultural awareness when developing change-management strategies, and implementing those strategies.

To effectively engage in this dialogue you will need to reflect on your own experiences in these areas and also review a range of earlier materials studied in other MBA (Change) specialisation courses, including, but not limited to, Unit 5 (Managing for organisational sustainability) in Systems for Change, the culture materials in Redesigning the Organisation, and the numerous ethical issues considered particularly in Approaches to Change. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"0654fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"4254bbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961960","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Contribution to Online Dialogues","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The specific questions for each online dialogue will be posted by your facilitator prior to the commencement of each dialogue period. Dialogues will focus on the content of this course and also provide broad opportunities to reflect on change-management materials from other change-specialisation courses. Some dialogues will focus on the progress of your research.

You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from this course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. Active participation and positive engagement will help develop a positive learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

You will receive feedback and grades for the online work after all four online dialogues are complete.

This is a capstone course and while for this assessment concepts will be drawn largely from this course, they may also be accessed from other courses.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1654fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Leadership Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment requires an oral presentation focusing specifically on your personal leadership of the change process. The assessment attracts 10% of the marks for the course and has two components:

1.     the content of the presentation assesses your ability to reflect on your own change-management leadership style, using appropriate concepts (5%)

2.     the delivery of the presentation assesses your oral presentation skills (5%).

The following guidelines will be of assistance in preparing your reflections on your leadership of the change-management process.

1.     Read Appendix 2 (Kanter, R M 2005, ‘Leadership for change: Enduring skills for change masters’, Harvard Business School). This paper will provide an orientation to change-leadership skills, but do not limit your thinking (and reflections) to this material.

2.     Review change-leadership materials in other MBA (Change) courses that you have studied (particularly Approaches to Change).

3.     Reflect on your experiences in the Change Management Research Project. These may provide valuable evidence for the conclusions in your presentation.

4.     Include in your presentation:

a.     your definition of change leadership

b.     a brief theoretical description of change leadership

c.      brief commentary on the importance of change leadership

d.     key reflections on what you have learned about your own change-leadership style (with brief examples). Include highlights only, perhaps two or three strengths and improvement possibilities.

e.     a consideration of one improvement possibility and outline a brief personal-development strategy.

This presentation is meant to be crisp and focused. Remember, it is directed to your examiner, so the style of your presentation can be tailored to an informed audience.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0654fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4e54bbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assignment requires a comprehensive report of your change-management research project. It must be a thoughtful and rigorous documentation of your research. Since action research is the research design, this report must include both the theoretical dimensions of your work and the practical aspects. It must show evidence of understanding of relevant concepts from all of the change courses you have studied, including the Change Management Research Project. You should also take the opportunity to show your ability to integrate concepts, i.e. use more than one concept to analyse an issue or develop a strategy, and consider the links between the concepts. This theoretical material must be integrated with your organisational experience, which will highlight your interactions with the organisational participants in your research and the issues experienced.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0654fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e54fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af496195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c654fbc4dbe1fc10fe4b322af4961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Report on Online Dialogues","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Change-management practitioners engage with teams frequently throughout the process of change. This might be, for example, as a leader or member of the change team, or with the senior executive team as a client, or perhaps various work teams participating in the change. The ability to participate collaboratively and responsibly in a team is therefore a critical asset for the change-management practitioner. The change-management practitioner must also be able to reflect on their own teamwork, and on the team’s processes and ability to achieve outcomes. This assignment addresses these issues.

Drawing on your experiences of the four online dialogues (in Weeks 1, 3, 4 and 8) and utilising relevant concepts on teams and teamwork from Change Skills and Redesigning the Organisation, consider the questions below. Note also that the assessment criteria for the online dialogues (above) that are directed to contributions to learning and conversation in many ways are in parallel (or have a strong nexus with) teamwork.

·        How were the online interactions similar to or different from team processes?

·        How effective was the online engagement? Why?

·        Reflect on your personal online engagement and identify your major strengths and potential areas for improvement.

Note that while the answers to these questions are suggestive of the use of tables and bullet points, your paper must have a substantial component written in prose compliant with the assessment criteria below.

Analytics","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9135.


Business analytics enables organisations to make quicker, better and more intelligent decisions to create business value in the broadest sense - potentially the difference between survival and extinction in an increasingly competitive world. Evidence-based decision-making supported by a data-driven culture is essential to the management of organisations.


Davenport and Harris (2007) define business analytics as 'the extensive use of data, statistical and quantitative analysis, explanatory and predictive models, and fact-based management to drive decisions and actions'. A key aspect of this definition is that analytics ultimately provides insight that is actioned - not just descriptions (e.g. customer segmentation) or predictive models (e.g. which customers are likely to churn). Analytic methods are being used in many and varied ways - for example, to predict consumer choices, to predict the likelihood of a medical condition, to analyse social networks and social media, to better manage traffic networks. There are many ways of creating value from data, especially when an organisation's internal data is combined with external and open data.


This course addresses the context of business analytics and the management actions required for organisations to manage business analytics such that they can create value from their data and make progress on the transformational journey to becoming data-driven. The course comprises three core areas: (1) managing data and sources of value, (2) the business analytics process, (3) navigating the organisational context.


As part of the business analytics process, you will build predictive models. This requires a basic understanding of statistics and therefore you will be required to study the material on regression provided by the Harvard Quantitative Methods online course during the first five weeks of the course. Information about the Harvard course and how to enrol in it will be provided to you in Moodle. Your regression knowledge will be assessed by a multiple-choice quiz.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d7aa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Quantitative Methods Online Course: Regression Section","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

You will be covering the Harvard material on regression as you take the first five Units of the Business Analytics course. This will ensure that you acquire the necessary statistical knowledge to work with the course material on predictive modelling and, more generally, are able to make effective and better-informed use of business analytics in your organisation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1baa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Predictive Modelling - Written report and oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The predictive modelling assignment is carried out in teams. You will be given a dataset, a description of the variables in the dataset, and some background on the business value and use of the data.

Your written report should cover the following:

1. The establishment of your team and its capabilities, by sharing and consolidating your data science profile as produced in Unit 2.

2. Details of:

a. Data exploration: explore the relationships in the dataset and provide a summary of your insights.

b. Predictive modelling: build a model(s) and explain how the model(s) can create business value through improved decision-making.

3. Identification of ‘feature engineering’ opportunities within the dataset and, where appropriate, a demonstration of how feature engineering can improve the performance of your predictive model. Feature engineering can be carried out within the predictive modelling software or outside as pre-processing (e.g. with Excel).

4. A short narrative regarding how the dataset might be extended, e.g. by adding open data, unstructured data, social media data.

Your oral presentation should:

take the form of a PowerPoint (or equivalent) presentation that summarises the business value opportunities arising from your analysis in a form suitable for presentation to the senior management team. The duration of the presentation should be a minimum of three minutes and no longer than five minutes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97aa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9faa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d3aa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3aa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"53aa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1A: Participation and engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. 

Details

You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way, we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

You will receive ungraded feedback on your participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark for participation at the end of the course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97aa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9faa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d3aa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6faa7b16db217050be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Business analytics capability development - Written report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"45","description":"

What is the current state of business analytics in your organisation?

The case organisation selected can be your current organisation, a previous organisation that you have worked for, or any other organisation to which you have access.

To assess the current capability, you may wish to administer the Business Analytics Capability Assessment (BACA) survey to key people in your case organisation. Alternatively, you may prefer to use the BACA as a structured interview/data collection guide, or indeed decide to use a different instrument entirely (the choice of instrument will need to be justified, though).

BACA is covered in Unit 8 and is available as an Excel spreadsheet in Moodle. More details on BACA assessment is covered in the textbook in the chapter on Analytics Methodology.

What should your organisation do next?

Based on your foregoing data collection, you should conduct an analysis (e.g. using techniques from the business analytics methodology in Unit 8) and prepare a set of recommendations for the CEO concerning the actions your case organisation should now take to develop its business analytics capability.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97aa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9faa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3aa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"dbaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961937","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfaa3b16db217050be4672f5f3961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9baa3b16db217050be4672f5f39619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1B: Analytics software familiarisation (DataRobot)","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

This task is formative. You will receive the full mark (5%) for completion of the task and 0% for non-completion.

You will receive an email invitation to sign up for a DataRobot user account. Follow the sign-up instructions and check that you can access DataRobot. Your class facilitator will provide details via Moodle of the familiarisation task to be performed in DataRobot.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9136 - Silicon Valley Study Tour","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9136.


Over the past few decades Silicon Valley and its startup ecosystem have consistently produced high growth companies that have come to dominate industries worldwide from pioneering companies like HP and Fairchild and technology giants like Apple and Google through to a new generation of disruptors like Uber and AirBnB. This course, which takes place in Silicon Valley, provides you with an opportunity to get deeper insight into the world's most successful startup ecosystem and to identify the lessons that can be learnt for countries and individual companies that are seeking to enhance innovation and foster greater levels of entrepreneurship. During this course you will meet with and gain insights from entrepreneurs, investors, executives and industry experts who are living and working in the Valley and will develop practical insights and a fresh perspective that you will be able to apply to your organisation big or small. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1ffde976dba9b050be4672f5f396193f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

At the conclusion of the-study tour students are required to submit an encompassing self-reflection report synthesizing the lessons learned from the whole experience. This report should not be longer than five pages. Although this report needs to use the daily reflection journal for inspiration, it is not supposed to be simply a synthesis of those journal entries. Instead, it needs to discuss explicitly how this whole experience has changed your previous standpoint and/or how you can use this experience to engage in further professional/ personal opportunities.

The appendix to this self-reflection report will be the pages of daily self-reflection journal in which you record your experiences while on the field-study trip. Each of the journal entries should expose how the occurrences and interactions you have experienced that day can be transformed in lessons for your professional practice and/or how these experiences can reveal new insights in terms of the assessment of the investment opportunity being evaluated by your team. It is important to note that these journals need to go deeper than being a mere recount of the events of the day. It needs to interpret the new information and integrate it with past experiences, and specifically, engage with the framework discussed in this class and discuss its personal implications in terms of professional development.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ebfde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"effde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"effde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"23fd6d76dba9b050be4672f5f3961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This course is based on experiential learning and for you to get the most from the experience it is important that you are present and that you are actively engaged in all. For this reason we have attached a substantial proportion of the assessment to attendance and participation. Throughout the study tour the facilitators will be monitoring your contributions to assess the extent to which you are adding value to the experience of the class as whole. The criteria that we will be using include

1.     Are they physically and mentally present? Are they ready to depart on time? Are they distracted and too often on their phones?

2.     Is the student willing to contribute to the discussion with the class and with the companies and representatives we meet with?

3.     Are they respectful in their engagements? Do they leave opportunities open for others to ask questions? Do they encourage and build on the contributions of others?

4.     Are they attempting to contribute to the understanding of the group as a whole or do they often just focus on narrow issues of their own interest?

5.     Are they good ambassadors of the group and AGSM? Do they express appreciation to the people the people that we meet? Are they behaving in a manner that will pave future opportunities for AGSM students in the region.

A couple of other points:

Success for us in the course is if we are in position to allocate high grades for this element to all participants in the program. If for some reason you are not meeting the standards we expect we will let you know during the study tour so you have an opportunity to recalibrate.To create opportunities for everyone to contribute to the learning experience of the class the facilitators will nominate particular groups to start and lead debriefs and discussion after company visits. This will be done on the ground during the study tour.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ebfde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"effde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"effde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ffd6d76dba9b050be4672f5f396197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"team bios and summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

This is a group assignment and should be completed prior to your departure for the US. This introduction will be provided to the organisations we visit on the field trip, as well as to our Australian ‘live case study’ organisations.  It’s very important that we have this information and that you are able to sell yourself to the people we will meet.

Each member of the group should put together a one-page summary for themselves, preferably including a headshot. You should also have a one-page summary of the team and the skills that you bring to the project. This can take whatever form you like but it should resemble the type of summary that you might find in a proposal for consulting work or the sort of summary you would include in a pitch deck for a startup proposal. You can also take the opportunity to discuss how you will work as a team, set expectations  and identify who will play what roles.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e7fde976dba9b050be4672f5f3961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67fd6d76dba9b050be4672f5f3961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultants report for company","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a written report to an Australian organisation that is interested in shifting some or all of its operations to Silicon Valley. 

For this course we are using live case studies to act as a vehicle for you to learn through. You will be provided with a brief on the company or have the opportunity to meet with the founder or company representative prior to deparrture to the US or on the first day of the study tour. Once the study tour is over your team should work by itself to write up the final report and recommendations. Having a concrete case study to look at the Silicon Valley ecosystem through will help you get a better understanding of the experience that an entrepreneur of company might have when thinking about moving their business or expanding across geographies.

While feedback from the case study organisation is important, and will be useful to you, it will not determine the final assessment of this task. Rather our focus will be on the extent to which you were able to draw on insights and conversations gained during the study tour, relevant academic and industry sources and your own experience and commercial acumen to provide a clear set of well-considered recommendations. The specific assessment criteria we will use for this written report include the following

1.     Was it clearly presented and did it contain clear recommendations? Was it written in a manner that was useful for company or organisation for which it was prepared?

2.     Given the information you were able to gather did you demonstrate a good understanding of some of the key issues facing the business or industry vertical in which the case study organisation operated?

3.     Did you draw a variety of useful sources including insights gained during the study tour, where appropriate academic frameworks and theories, government reports, industry reports and examples of other business in the same industry or in an adjacent market?

To accompany the written report you are also expected to prepare a short (no more than 5 minute) video pitch that summarises the key findings of the report. You can use any format you like for this element. We will be happy to provide some recommendations during the study tour. From a learning goal perspective it is designed to provide evidence of your team’s oral communication skills but is also something that we can share with the case study organisation. While in Silicon Valley you may consider taking videos and photos that could be included in your video presentation.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9137.


This course focuses on advanced financial decisions of corporate managers. First, the course expands on the traditional project evaluation criteria by introducing real options and valuation techniques in the presence of uncertainly. Second, it explains the nuances associated with various forms of debt finance. Third, it explains how to hedge a company's cash flows and balance sheet from both domestic and international exposures. The course uses case studies to illustrate the application of theoretical concepts to real-life.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a3f545f6dbe5b050be4672f5f396196f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment includes a series of weekly online quizzes on the course website that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. There are 8 quizzes in total based on Units 1,2,3,5,6,7,9 and 10 and they are due in Weeks 2 to 11.

Each quiz will consist of 5 questions. Most questions are multiple-choice style but there are also a few calculation questions. You will have 1 hour to complete each quiz from the time you first open it. Your final grade will be based on your best 6 quiz scores. For more detailed information about this assessment including the start and finish times for each quiz, please refer to the 'Quiz Instructions' document under the 'Quizzes' section of the course website.

The assignment involves writing an analysis of a case study. You will be allocated into a group of between 3 and 4 students. Only one submission is required per group. More detail on each case study and the questions that must be answered will be available in the 'Case Study Instructions' document under the 'Case Studies' section of the course website.

The final assessment is an online exam that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. It will be performed on Moodle course site and will involve a mix of multiple choice style questions, multi-part problem style questions and also some short-essay questions. The questions will be based on Units 1 to 10 of the course. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Exam Instructions' document under the 'Exam' section in Moodle.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9137.

This course focuses on advanced financial decisions of corporate managers. First, the course expands on the traditional project evaluation criteria by introducing real options and valuation techniques in the presence of uncertainly. Second, it explains the nuances associated with various forms of debt finance. Third, it explains how to hedge a company's cash flows and balance sheet from both domestic and international exposures. The course uses case studies to illustrate the application of theoretical concepts to real-life.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9138.


The practical aim of this course is to present the tools necessary to undertake business analysis using financial statement information, and to show how these tools can be applied to a wide range of decision-making contexts. We aim to provide you with up-to-date applied knowledge of fundamental valuation techniques, pitfalls of accounting reports, and "reading between the lines" of financial reports.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"410801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e6","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Open Book Test 1 & 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment 1 comprises two online open-book tests. These will comprise a combination of multiple-choice, true/false and matching-pairs questions, as well as some numerical and financial calculations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"490801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d0801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"190801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Take-home Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will complete a take-home assessment task that will consist of questions designed to assess your comprehension of the material we will cover in the course. They will be based around a current, real company’s financial statements.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"410801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"410801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"490801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"490801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"490801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"490801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d0801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"450801badbe5b050be4672f5f39619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project (Case Study)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment 2 is a group project (case study) that requires students to work in groups of five (5) to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of a publicly listed company, and to submit a written report and digital presentation at the end of Week 8.

Specifically, the group project requires students to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of a listed company.

Weekly group project activities are embedded throughout the the online course website, up until submission in Week 8. 

The team should plan how it will undertake the work for the group project.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9139 - Entrepreneurial Finance","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9139.


This course seeks to understand what venture capital is, what venture capitalists do and the way venture capital organisations work. This course is primarily geared towards students interested in working in venture capital, or other private-equity organizations. It is also intended for students who expect to work alongside venture capitalists or other private equity investors, whether as managers of firms financed by such investors, as investment bankers taking their firms public, or as money managers investing in these funds. Finally, it is designed for students interested in exploring how aspects of private equity investing can be transferred to the management of projects in established organizations.

The objective of quizzes (approx 2) mostly quantitative in nature, is to apply the techniques developed during the course.  Approximately two quizzes in week 3 and 6.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8b698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The objective of this group assignment is to apply the ideas and principles developed in the course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"83698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"83698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8b698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8b698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"43698dfadbe5b050be4672f5f39619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The objective of the final assignment is to test whether you have achieved the learning objectives of Units 1 to 10 of the course.  Answers should include using the models, theories and methodologies that are taught in the units that are being assessed. Broad answers not only on common-sense or your own experiences. Where appropriate,  answers should briefly explore multiple points of view and identify any flaws in your own analysis.

contentlets.keywords: mbax,mergers and acquisitions,corporate finance,global finance,financial analysis,entrepreneurial finance,mbax9139
contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9139.

This course seeks to understand what venture capital is, what venture capitalists do and the way venture capital organisations work. This course is primarily geared towards students interested in working in venture capital, or other private-equity organizations. It is also intended for students who expect to work alongside venture capitalists or other private equity investors, whether as managers of firms financed by such investors, as investment bankers taking their firms public, or as money managers investing in these funds. Finally, it is designed for students interested in exploring how aspects of private equity investing can be transferred to the management of projects in established organizations.
contentlets.title: Entrepreneurial Finance

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9140.


This course is a joint activity between the Institute of Global Finance at the UNSW Business School and the Volatility Insitute at Stern Business School, NYU. The course will provide information and analysis on the latest developments in the world of finance and their implications for business strategies. The course will use articles from The Wall Street Journal and The Financial Times to complement a number of issues that influence global finance and the way multinational companies build their global business networks, their activities and strategies. The latest issues on global finance will be taught in this course, with online lectures, videos and other online materials. 


The basic thrust of this course is to provide a framework within which the key global financial issues, including financial risk and the operations of multinational companies, can be analysed. This course is designed to develop students' understanding of the business and financial aspects of their main specialisation.


The course prepares students for leadership roles and builds understanding of global financial forces that could influence the overall business environment. There will be some videos of experts from KPMG, eminent scholars in finance from the US who will share their insights on aspects of global finance.

Each group of three to four students will be given a multinational company to study. The focus of the group project is on evaluation students' understanding of a way they study one large multinational company's operation with a focus on these following 4 core aspects:

\n\n
  1. Business strategies
  2. Financial risk management
  3. Social and cultural awareness of the business situation in its overall operations
  4. Ethical transparency, social and/or environmental responsibility in is decision-making process
\n\n

A more detailed outline of the exact requirements of the Group Project will be communicated in week 1.

Acquisitions","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9141.


The objective of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to successfully initiate, analyse, evaluate and implement M&A transactions. The course will explore the development and execution of transactions including business acquisitions, takeovers, divestments, and initial public offerings. In addition, students will consider corporate and business strategies that motivate M&A transactions and the motivations of financial buyers such as private equity participants in M&A markets. Students will learn to assess targets and value target businesses by applying corporate finance tools and knowledge within the context of evaluating, developing and executing M&A transactions. The course emphasises the practical applications of skills and knowledge through a combination of case studies, group activities and online discussions.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8bc09536db29b050be4672f5f396191a","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 Task C: Critique of M&A proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

In this third component of Assessment 3, multiple student peers in the cohort — the exact number will depend on the number of enrolments and the number of teams — will independently respond to a team’s M&A proposal and determine the three most important questions to ask the team of “advisors” who put forward the proposal.

Each student has the option to evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for Assessment 3. Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your teammates will not know what marks you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Individual growth strategy and M&A valuation paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is an individual development of a strategy involving identification and justification of an M&A target and valuation of the M&A target from the position of the chosen case study business. This work is presented in the form of a management working paper.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8bc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1bc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The first assessment is composed of five small quizzes that act as an active, formative learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning.

Quiz 1A Due: Week 2 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1B Due: Week 4 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1C Due: Week 6 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1D Due: Week 8 Weighting: 3%

Quiz 1E Due: Week 10 Weighting: 3%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"47c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Ongoing throughout the term

The purpose of online class participation is to help you develop your ideas through active interaction and engagement with your peers and the facilitator. You should incorporate concepts, models, frameworks and theories from the course when expressing your ideas, and use appropriate analysis and justification when expressing coherent concise points of view. You should also expand on, and drive, the conversation by meaningfully responding to contributions from other students.

Three types of student contributions are possible during the flow of discussions with fellow classmates. These are:

  • Original posts created in response to the posed weekly activity or question
  • Response posts where you address the replies other students have made to your original post.
  • Reply posts made to other students’

Original Posts that you make should be up to 250 words. Responses and replies should be up to approximately half this length. The goal is to be concise and to avoid writing essays in a discussion.

Note that your facilitator may set specific activities and interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

Feedback

You will receive feedback on your level of participation at the mid-point of the course and a final mark at the end of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"afc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 Task A: Development of an M&A proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment builds directly on the individual team members' work on Assessment 2. The team can share and review the insights provided by Assessment 2 as a form of past research, but the proposal developed for this Assessment is an extension of the ground work provided by Assessment 2. Importantly, the team now works together as corporate advisors or consultants to the chosen business to develop a unique, cohesive and comprehensive strategy for M&A value creation for the focus organisation. In this assessment the team will develop and present a comprehensive proposal for value creation through M&A plus supporting material. The proposal is to include a single or multiple M&A transactions and may also include divestments. Importantly the M&A proposal should present a convincing argument and feasible plan for the management of the organisation to pursue the M&A proposal and address important points for the management to consider in making a decision to pursue the proposed strategy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87c0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8bc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"8fc0d536db29b050be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d7c0d536db29b050be4672f5f3961925","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/AGSM9141.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: mbax,mergers and acquisitions,corporate finance,global finance,financial analysis,entrepreneurial finance,mbax9141
contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9141.

The objective of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to successfully initiate, analyse, evaluate and implement M&A transactions. The course will explore the development and execution of transactions including business acquisitions, takeovers, divestments, and initial public offerings. In addition, students will consider corporate and business strategies that motivate M&A transactions and the motivations of financial buyers such as private equity participants in M&A markets. Students will learn to assess targets and value target businesses by applying corporate finance tools and knowledge within the context of evaluating, developing and executing M&A transactions. The course emphasises the practical applications of skills and knowledge through a combination of case studies, group activities and online discussions.
contentlets.title: Mergers and Acquisitions
