Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9142 - Financial Modelling","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously offered as MBAX9142.


Financial Modelling intends to make managers more confident and effective users of financial models, helping them to better understand and communicate the practical value of financial models, and to build this literacy for their future work. Key to this is a critical pedagogical approach which develops and refines students’ high-level critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, alongside providing them with a set of practical tools and techniques to help them make effective judgments about a business’s current financial situation and future performance based on best practice financial modelling principles.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961994","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: Pizza Planet amendment #2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

In this task, you will once again update your case study model, this time to change the way in which tax losses operate. We chose this task specifically because it is one of the most complex challenges that financial modellers face in their roles. If you are able to successfully complete this task, you can have the confidence to tackle any challenge that the world of financial modelling throws at you.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"112c11b2db69b050be4672f5f39619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1A : Introductory modelling task","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

In this task, you will be required to construct a financial model to assist with deciding whether it is better to buy the home you live in, or rent and invest in an index fund. The purpose of this task is to give you an opportunity to experience how difficult it can be to build a robust financial model without a solid foundation of best practices to lean on. Given this task is assigned at the start of the course (before we have taught you anything), you will not be assessed on the quality of your output, but rather the quality of a reflection that you will prepare, outlining your approach and struggles.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"552c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d2c11b2db69b050be4672f5f39619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Capstone modelling task","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment will require you to build a financial model from scratch for a fictitious social media company called Fakebook. Your financial model will need to forecast the three financial statements in an integrated manner, based on a set of background information that will be provided. You will then use your model to answer a series of quiz questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"552c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"312c51b2db69b050be4672f5f3961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Final Online Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will last 90 minutes and contains 20 questions, each worth 1 mark. These questions will comprise:

  • 6 questions that test your Excel knowledge
  • 5 questions that test your financial modelling knowledge
  • 3 questions that test your ability to solve complex logic problems using Excel
  • 6 questions that test your ability to develop a financial model

The 6 questions that test your ability to develop a financial model will involve you downloading some background information and an Excel file containing a partially completed model. You will be required to complete the missing logic in that model, and then use the results of your formulas to answer the 6 questions. You will also be required to upload your completed model as part of the assessment.

The questions will be a combination of multiple choice, true/false and numerical answers. All topics covered throughout the course can be tested, and we would advise that as part of your preparation, you should:

  • Watch all videos in their entirety at least once.
  • Complete the Pizza Planet case study and correctly answer all the status check questions.
  • Revise each of the stand-alone Excel activities that were introduced throughout the course.
  • Complete the practice questions provided in the sample test which will be made available to you. This sample test provides a good indication of the style of questions that you will encounter.

The assessment will be open book and you can reference any of the course materials that you think may help you. Naturally, you will need to sit the assessment on a computer that has Microsoft Excel installed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"552c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"712c51b2db69b050be4672f5f3961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Pizza Planet amendment #1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

In this task, you will take the case study model that we have been developing together and amend it to reflect a new public holiday. You will use your updated model to answer a series of questions. This task is aimed at giving you an opportunity to experience what it is like to amend an existing model (and all the dangers that entails).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"552c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a52c51b2db69b050be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1B : Modelling critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This task follows on from the introductory modelling task, and it will give you an opportunity to further reflect on your attempt, this time with reference to the best practice principles that you will learn throughout the course. We hope that in genuinely undertaking this reflection, you will be able to gauge how far you have come on your learning journey.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"512c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"552c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"592c9d72db69b050be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a92c11b2db69b050be4672f5f39619fe","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/AGSM9142.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously offered as MBAX9142.

Financial Modelling intends to make managers more confident and effective users of financial models, helping them to better understand and communicate the practical value of financial models, and to build this literacy for their future work. Key to this is a critical pedagogical approach which develops and refines students’ high-level critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, alongside providing them with a set of practical tools and techniques to help them make effective judgments about a business’s current financial situation and future performance based on best practice financial modelling principles.
contentlets.title: Financial Modelling

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9150 - Digital Innovation","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9150.


Innovation and the management of technology are critical in driving economic productivity and improving the future wellbeing of society. Advances in the accessibility of modern technology, and increasingly connected social and alternative financing methods have decreased barriers in the practice of entrepreneurship, enabling digital innovation to flourish. As a result, digital innovation is empowering many people, from digital natives to those living in developing countries, to create solutions and drive change. In addition, the speed at which entrepreneurs can disrupt established business practices is causing more organisations to adopt agile and entrepreneurial methods for developing and managing new technology, products and services.

In Weeks 1 to 10 there will be an online quiz testing your knowledge of the core curriculum readings. Each quiz will consist of four true/false or multiple-choice questions. You will have eight minutes to complete each quiz and cannot revisit a question once the answer for that question has been submitted.

\n

Out of the 10 quizzes, your best eight results will be used to determine your mark for this assessment.

Active participation, engagement, and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative.

\n

Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

\n

You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 4 and a final mark at the end of the course.

Each student may optionally evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for this assessment. This evaluation is scored out of 10.

\n

This process allows students to more clearly indicate the apportioning of workload within the team that actually occurred. The task is optional as it may not be necessary to do this if the team performed well in its tasks.

\n

Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your team mates will not know what rating you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"eb367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c467b9edbed3050be4672f5f39619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4A: Final Course Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is an opportunity for students to identify a digital innovation either in their own work place or elsewhere and make a presentation on its virtues. Students will, in groups, create a venture plan either for an internal corporate venture, or for a startup venture.

\n

The assessment can include, but is not restricted to, the following elements:

\n

1. Digital innovation of interest and background

\n

2. Rationale for selection or motivation with level of maturity of the digital innovation, can be early conceptual or mature

\n

3. Benefit to society / business, etc.

\n

4. Use case by client with key features

\n

5. Examples of implementation if any in society or organisations

\n

6. Financial viability of the digital innovation, with capital needs

\n

7. Improvements into the future of current technical characteristics

\n

8. Recommendation of the digital innovation in terms of uses / business value / customer segments.

\n

9. Adequate referencing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"e3367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"e3367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e7363b9edbed3050be4672f5f396191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eb367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"eb367b9edbed3050be4672f5f396197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"ef363b9edbed3050be4672f5f396191d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63367b9edbed3050be4672f5f3961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Conference proceedings on an emerging technology","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will develop a conference proceeding in the form of a presentation. Your boss, the Chief Technology Officer, has been asked to present to an international conference (student to select) on an emerging technology or innovation they are exploring and are promoting the potential use, implementation and commercialisation opportunity. This could include what has been done recently and their experiences so far. The problem is, the CTO has been asked to attend an executive off-site, and you have the chance to pull this together and promote your organisation.

\n

Students will look at an emerging digital innovation that may impact society and/ or businesses but is yet to be commercialised. Students will explore various Gartner Hype Cycles to be able to identify a suitable emerging innovation. Aspects to explore could be, but are not limited to, the following:

\n
  1. A clear definition of the innovation
  2. The maturity level, i.e. is it still in the research phase, prototype or is it ready for trials/testing
  3. The overall value to industry and organisation
  4. Potential benefits to the customer base. Identify which customer base you intend to serve
  5. How would the solution/s be implemented?
  6. What could be the risks?
  7. What financial benefit / value could be derived from a potential solution/s?
  8. What time frame would you envisage for a ROI?
\n

Hint: the blockchain / bitcoin, driverless cars, biometrics have had a similar journey.

\n

Students will then present the potential opportunities should this innovation be commercialised.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9150.

Innovation and the management of technology are critical in driving economic productivity and improving the future wellbeing of society. Advances in the accessibility of modern technology, and increasingly connected social and alternative financing methods have decreased barriers in the practice of entrepreneurship, enabling digital innovation to flourish. As a result, digital innovation is empowering many people, from digital natives to those living in developing countries, to create solutions and drive change. In addition, the speed at which entrepreneurs can disrupt established business practices is causing more organisations to adopt agile and entrepreneurial methods for developing and managing new technology, products and services.
contentlets.title: Digital Innovation

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9151 - Law, Regulation & Ethics","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9151. 


Organisations and the individuals who work in them need to ensure that they operate lawfully and in a manner that meets stakeholder expectations and broader community standards of acceptable behaviour. This is true across business entities, not-for-profits and in the business of government. It requires managers to understand and be accountable for compliance with a complex array of legal and non-legal rules and expectations, derived from different sources. The reputational risk which flows from decisions influenced by personal, professional and institutional ethics can be amplified enormously by social media. This course is designed to equip students with the analytical tools to identify and manage the governance, compliance and risk management issues that arise from law, regulation and ethics in the context of businesses’ relationship with society. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961973","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Video Presentation and Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are expected to present in a group on a case.

In Week 1, the facilitator will upload a video explaining the background, context and events of Case 1 (Rana Plaza).

For subsequent weeks, students will work in teams to prepare and upload/share a similar presentation on the case to which they are assigned (which will then be used for that week's discussion activity).

This will be in the format of video added to an Outlook 365 PowerPoint file.

This must be uploaded to Moodle on Sunday evening by 5pm - that is, one day prior to the week in which the case is to be discussed. This ensures the discussion can start promptly and without delay.

In addition to the video, each team needs to produce a short (2 page) summary of their presentation/case overview. Because these case studies have complex facts the summary is a useful aid for your colleagues to ensure they have the basic facts and details about the case. It may also help you in preparing your script for the presentation (in fact it may be an edited version of the script). The summary should be uploaded at the same time as the video.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5f1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Case Analysis - Outline and Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment 3 requires you to analyse and reflect on one of the Cases discussed during the course. Each Case we study raises a range of issues that are not limited to the specific Unit in which it was discussed.

This assessment task gives you the chance to reflect more broadly on the issues of law, regulation and ethics faced by the industry, entity or individuals involved in the selected Case.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ab1694eedb617050be4672f5f396198f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Forum Contribution and Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

In Weeks 2 to 10 there will be prompts for online discussion by the whole class. Each student is expected to contribute to that discussion. The discussion for each week will be on a forum on Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"531694eedb617050be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5f1694eedb617050be4672f5f3961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d71694eedb617050be4672f5f3961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3B: Case Analysis - Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The Final Report is a research essay that uses the Case you have selected to draw out and explore issues of law, regulation and ethics. Each Case involves a sector, entity or individual engaging in conduct that caused or may cause harm, and demonstrates the challenges faced by society in setting and enforcing normative standards for business and by business in achieving meaningful compliance. How would a well-governed, sustainable and responsible entity manage those risks?

Your Final Report should identify and engage with those challenges, and explore conceptual and practical ways of addressing them.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9152 - Digital Strategy","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9152.


This course focuses on the key concepts, practices and issues in the strategic management of digital technologies. The course covers two key themes. First, the course begins with examining the strategic role and organisational value of digital technologies, including digitally-enabled innovation, digital ecosystems, and digital transformation and disruption. Second, the course examines the strategic management of digital technologies required to realise this value potential, including current and emerging approaches and frameworks for strategic decision-making about digital technologies, and the management of digital service delivery.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f396199d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2A: Weekly blogs","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

In Weeks 2 through 9, write one blog per week (a total of eight blogs). The blog post activity is described in the unit materials where you are asked to reflect on and respond to a set of questions focused on the weekly theme. You will use a blogging platform to author your weekly posts. More details will be made available in Moodle about this activity and use of the blogging tool.

Each blog should be related to a central theme. The blog posts should be based on a company which is not the same as the one used in the group project.

Please ensure you research your response and include references where relevant.

Your blog must be an individual effort. Each blog post should be no more than 300 words in length. References are excluded from this word count.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"eb4373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c5373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation through Class Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Active participation and interaction with peers is a vital ingredient in learning and is assessed on your contributions to discussion and other learning activities in the class. You need to incorporate the concepts and theories from the course when expressing your own ideas, experience and opinions, and when responding to comments and contributions from your fellow students. In this way, we develop a learning environment that is supportive, dynamic and informative. Note that your facilitator may set specific interactive tasks for you to complete as part of this assessment.

Please ensure after making your initial post that you respond to at least 2 of your class mates.

Note that to improve the class discussions we will be breaking up large classes into smaller discussion groups. These groups will be assigned automatically and are likely to have about 10 members per group.

You will receive feedback on your participation at the end of Week 5 and a final mark at the end of the course.

In the content for each Unit, there is one designated class discussion activity focused on discussing a specific set of questions with your teammates. Every team will have a Moodle forum thread set up to serve as a platform for discussing the team activity. In your forum thread, you should seek to both contribute new, independent insights as well as to respond and build on the ideas of others.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e74373dadbed3050be4672f5f396199e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eb4373dadbed3050be4672f5f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"774373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2B: Commentary on your best 5 blogs","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In Part B you will choose the 5 blogs that you connected with the most and format them into one coherent submission. You will have an additional 500 words which you can use for an introduction, conclusion or to add to the blogs. You are allowed to rewrite your blogs before final submission.

Each student may optionally evaluate the contribution made by each member of their team for this assessment. This evaluation is scored out of 10.

This process allows students to more clearly indicate the apportioning of workload within the team that actually occurred. The task is optional as it may not be necessary to do this if the team performed well in its tasks.

Evaluations will be confidential – that is, your team mates will not know what rating you have awarded to them or see the comments you make.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"e34373dadbed3050be4672f5f396199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f34373dadbed3050be4672f5f39619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Develop a Digital Strategy","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Your team report should include and address the items below, in the order in which they are presented.

Task 1: Industry analysis
(20% of assignment marks)

Analyse the competitive forces affecting the industry in which your organisation operates. What are the key drivers of competitive advantage in this industry? How, if at all, are these drivers changing?

Task 2: Business strategy analysis
(20% of assignment marks)

Review and summarise your organisation’s business strategy and business practices. How does your organisation aim to differentiate itself from its key competitors? Discuss how much emphasis your organisation currently places on digital technologies in its business strategy.

Task 3: Digital trends
(20% of assignment marks)

Identify and discuss the opportunities and threats that increasing digitisation poses for your organisation. You may want to refer to your work in Unit 3 to help you work through this task. Discuss the impact of each of the trends you identify, considering your organisation’s strategy and competitive environment.

Task 4: Recommendations
(30% of assignment marks)

Recommend three key emerging technologies that your organisation should invest in to gain competitive advantage and/or to remain competitive. Using specific examples, discuss how your organisation should use each of these technologies for strategic value. Discuss how your organisation may need to change its business strategy or practices to successfully leverage these technologies.

Presentation style/effectiveness
(10% of assignment marks)

The presentation will be evaluated on its logical and coherent structure; the smooth flow of ideas; the effectiveness of the delivery and communication, and appearance of visual aids, including appropriate use of tables and diagrams. For referencing, please use the Harvard Referencing style (https://student.unsw.edu.au/harvard-referencing).

The presentation will be evaluated on its logical and coherent structure; the smooth flow of ideas; the effectiveness of the delivery and communication, and appearance of visual aids, including appropriate use of tables and diagrams. For referencing, please use the Harvard Referencing style (https://student.unsw.edu.au/harvard-referencing).

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9152.

This course focuses on the key concepts, practices and issues in the strategic management of digital technologies. The course covers two key themes. First, the course begins with examining the strategic role and organisational value of digital technologies, including digitally-enabled innovation, digital ecosystems, and digital transformation and disruption. Second, the course examines the strategic management of digital technologies required to realise this value potential, including current and emerging approaches and frameworks for strategic decision-making about digital technologies, and the management of digital service delivery.
contentlets.title: Digital Strategy

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"AGSM9153 - Implementing Strategy","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9153.


This course provides students with applied, critical thinking and application skills for effective strategy implementation. With a focus on a spectrum of principles and features that influence strategy execution, it helps develop practical insights into organisational transformation. The course aligns with the content of other strategy courses, but focuses on the spectrum of issues to translate strategy implementation detailing how organisations can achieve sustained effectiveness with both its current challenges and future possibilities. In this context, the course deals with themes on the strategic process of managing for change, redesigning structure, human capital and talent management, and smart responses to technology. The course challenges students to think critically and develop useful insights about the concepts and principles on making better strategy. 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"28496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Team-based Activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"12","description":"

Three times during the course you are expected to complete short activities directly related to Unit content. These activities need to be completed in your study team (formed in Week 1). These activities vary in what they require you to do but are applications on content that teams need to present, defend, or promote. They do not require extra reading or preparation but are a means for you to extend Unit content and your understanding of it in a fun and interactive way. Each activity is meant to encourage critical thinking, presentation development, and problem-solving skills by directly applying course content. These activities take place in weeks when you do not have other assessments. Instructions for each activity is given in the units in which they appear.

Unit 3: Present a 1-page slide response (“How does a firm know if its organizational design is appropriate for its strategy?”) – 3%

Unit 5: Debate your peers to make your case (“Strategic agility is a waste of productive time. After all, sustained strategy implementation in VUCA really needs clear direction and consistent leadership.”) – 4%

Unit 7: Make a soapbox presentation to speak up about a statement on human capital (aligning human capital with strategy) - 5%

Weighting: 12% total

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Group Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

For this report, in your team, carry out a critical analysis and assessment of a failed or poor strategy implementation. Select a case and organisation that has undergone strategy change or transformation to evaluate the lessons learned and to extend application from the implementation. Historical examples include Polaroid’s digital camera; the online pet supply retailing, and Dick Smith, while prominent recent examples include Tata Nano, Toys R Us and the NBN. The focus is not on bankruptcy or terminal failure but on strategy implementation that led to failures and poor outcomes. It is your responsibility to find and select the case and organisation and to prepare the report. Before commencing your report, you will need to confirm your organisation selection with your class facilitator. The key to your selection is to narrow your focus rather than attempt to undertake a full industry and strategy assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a0496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

In this assessment you are required to produce a short video reflection. Given the many variants available to developing and implementing strategy, the choices and challenges available to strategists are diverse. In this course we have attempted to give shape to some of the issues and dimensions available in crafting and executing strategy, guided by insights into the planning, thinking, critical insights, and mindsets that accompanying effective strategy. That is, highlighting that strategy implementation is both a set plan and a shape-shifting exercise, guided by strategist choice. 

In this final assessment, you now turn to reflecting on the strategic conversations that you have had over the term and with your colleagues. Built around content, the exercise is meant to enable you to identify key takeaways that were meaningful to you and to deconstruct or understand them based on what you learned. This is a different format to extend ideas and show your understanding. It is personal application, meant to encourage deep thinking and insightful analysis.

You are expected to participate and contribute to discussion (in online dialogues for the online mode, and in class dialogue interactions in the intensive mode)

Online Dialogue: Within each online dialogue activity, each student is required to make postings at least twice in the week to allow reasonable dialogue with other students. The maximum word count of each posting is 200 words. For these Units, there is an explicit dialogue activity that each student needs to prepare to discuss in class. Each student should expect to contribute to team and whole class discussions.

Dialogues take place in Weeks 1, 2, 6 and 8

Weighting: Each participation week is worth 2% for a total of 8%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Individual Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In this course, we assume that the formulation and implementation of strategy are intertwined as complex, interactive processes in which politics, values, organisational culture, and management styles determine or constrain particular strategic decisions. In exploring this theme we consider two different schools of thought on how to approach strategy – planned strategy and strategic thinking. With this divergence we recognise (Unit 2) that strategy can be an open system that interrelates strategy elements as they evolve, or a comprehensive management model that links strategy and operations, considering effective strategy development, planning, and management tools to achieve sustainable strategic success. 

At the heart of this discussion is a fundamental difference on what effective strategy implementation looks like, that: (1) a formal, planned strategy is essential to enable strategic success, or (2) formal planning is not the best way to develop strategy because strategy needs intuition and crafting. 

Recognising this distinction, for this assessment use either a crafting strategy (Mintzberg, unit 1) or a strategic planning (Kaplan and Norton, unit 2) frame to critically evaluate your organisation’s current primary strategy and its implementation (or alternatively, if not possible for an organisation you have recently worked for). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a0496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e8496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619c2","links":[]}]},{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"60496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Team-based Activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"12","description":"

Three times during the course you are expected to complete short activities directly related to Unit content. These activities need to be completed in your study team (formed in Week 1). These activities vary in what they require you to do but are applications on content that teams need to present, defend, or promote. They do not require extra reading or preparation but are a means for you to extend Unit content and your understanding of it in a fun and interactive way. Each activity is meant to encourage critical thinking, presentation development, and problem-solving skills by directly applying course content. These activities take place in weeks when you do not have other assessments. Instructions for each activity is given in the units in which they appear.

Unit 3: Present a 1-page slide response (“How does a firm know if its organizational design is appropriate for its strategy?”) – 3%

Unit 5: Debate your peers to make your case (“Strategic agility is a waste of productive time. After all, sustained strategy implementation in VUCA really needs clear direction and consistent leadership.”) – 4%

Unit 7: Make a soapbox presentation to speak up about a statement on human capital (aligning human capital with strategy) - 5%

Weighting: 12% total

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"24496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Group Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

For this report, in your team, carry out a critical analysis and assessment of a failed or poor strategy implementation. Select a case and organisation that has undergone strategy change or transformation to evaluate the lessons learned and to extend application from the implementation. Historical examples include Polaroid’s digital camera; the online pet supply retailing, and Dick Smith, while prominent recent examples include Tata Nano, Toys R Us and the NBN. The focus is not on bankruptcy or terminal failure but on strategy implementation that led to failures and poor outcomes. It is your responsibility to find and select the case and organisation and to prepare the report. Before commencing your report, you will need to confirm your organisation selection with your class facilitator. The key to your selection is to narrow your focus rather than attempt to undertake a full industry and strategy assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a0496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a4496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c496f8bdb22fc90595850d8f49619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

In this assessment you are required to produce a short video reflection. Given the many variants available to developing and implementing strategy, the choices and challenges available to strategists are diverse. In this course we have attempted to give shape to some of the issues and dimensions available in crafting and executing strategy, guided by insights into the planning, thinking, critical insights, and mindsets that accompanying effective strategy. That is, highlighting that strategy implementation is both a set plan and a shape-shifting exercise, guided by strategist choice. 

In this final assessment, you now turn to reflecting on the strategic conversations that you have had over the term and with your colleagues. Built around content, the exercise is meant to enable you to identify key takeaways that were meaningful to you and to deconstruct or understand them based on what you learned. This is a different format to extend ideas and show your understanding. It is personal application, meant to encourage deep thinking and insightful analysis.

At the heart of this discussion is a fundamental difference on what effective strategy implementation looks like, that: (1) a formal, planned strategy is essential to enable strategic success, or (2) formal planning is not the best way to develop strategy because strategy needs intuition and crafting. 

Recognising this distinction, for this assessment use either a crafting strategy (Mintzberg, unit 1) or a strategic planning (Kaplan and Norton, unit 2) frame to critically evaluate your organisation’s current primary strategy and its implementation (or alternatively, if not possible for an organisation you have recently worked for).

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9153.

This course provides students with applied, critical thinking and application skills for effective strategy implementation. With a focus on a spectrum of principles and features that influence strategy execution, it helps develop practical insights into organisational transformation. The course aligns with the content of other strategy courses, but focuses on the spectrum of issues to translate strategy implementation detailing how organisations can achieve sustained effectiveness with both its current challenges and future possibilities. In this context, the course deals with themes on the strategic process of managing for change, redesigning structure, human capital and talent management, and smart responses to technology. The course challenges students to think critically and develop useful insights about the concepts and principles on making better strategy.
contentlets.title: Implementing Strategy

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9154 - Managing with Digital Technology","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9154.


Managing with Digital Technology aims to increase technical literacy of managers and leaders. The main objective of this course is to give managers a high-level overview of the fundamental concepts, main topics and problems in computer science and information technology and how they relate to business settings, and thus equip them to make better decisions regarding applications of technology, even if they are not technologists themselves. This course takes a top-down approach and emphasises high-level mastery of important concepts in computer science and information technology. Students who successfully complete this course will feel confident in any technology organisation and will have an appreciation for the problems in the field, how they affect or constrain business decisions and how it all works.


The course prepares students for product-management roles. Product manager is increasingly becoming the job of choice for MBA students. Similarly, more and more industries, especially traditional service industries, are creating their own products to deliver more capabilities to their customers and require new capabilities from their managers. Being a product manager requires similar skills to a CEO, which combined with the perceived attractiveness of working in the tech industry, makes it an attractive career path for graduating MBA and management students. A successful product manager needs to master the business side of developing a product as well as be able to interact with a wide range of technical and non-technical stakeholders - from customers through to product engineers and user experience specialists.


Managing with Digital Technology equips founders to succeed in technology endeavors. Successful start-up founders will come across technology from day zero. Virtually every business idea today involves technology - often entire stacks of various technologies. Founders with a non-technical background must rely entirely on their technical co-founders, if they are lucky, or on the word of developers and other technologists they hire, to help them realise their dream. They are often faced with difficult choices and this course aims to equip them with the knowledge and confidence to make informed choices not just in business but in technology as well.

Students will undertake Readiness Assurance Tests (RATs) at the beginning of each week. This will motivate students to familiarise themselves with the material before the ensuing discussions and will contribute to a higher quality of debate. The RATs will accompany every unit. 

There will be 10 RATS - each RAT contributing 1% of overall mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ab19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ab19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Group case analysis and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The second assessment will be an analysis and evaluation of a case study after which students will be required to develop a technology strategy for the company in the case. This assessment will synthesise the knowledge from the Foundational Building Block units of the course with the aim of cementing the basics for students and will form a natural mid-term break point in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a319bf92db217050be4672f5f3961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a319bf92db217050be4672f5f3961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a319bf92db217050be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ab19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2b19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Individual report - strategy operationalisation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The fourth assessment will be an extension of the Assessment 2. Students will re-visit the case and strategy they created earlier and will now extend the strategy by operationalising it. This will see students develop deliverables such as a technical staff development plan and a target operating model that will enable the company from the case study to operationalise the strategy that was created earlier. The assessment by nature will have flexibility in how students can address the question and there will be multiple paths that students can take in completing the assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a319bf92db217050be4672f5f3961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ab19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"af19bf92db217050be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6319bf92db217050be4672f5f396196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Multiple-choice test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The third assessment will be closely industry aligned. The assessment will be a multiple-choice test designed to test the student's knowledge of best practices in digital product development. The multiple-choice questions will, among other things, test the student's knowledge of industry standard terms as defined in the publicly available Scrum Body of Knowledge. Structuring the assessment as such will synthesise and solidify the knowledge that students gain from the second part of the course focused on product management. After this assessment, students will be well positioned to take the full Professional Scrum Master certification, should they choose to. The aim is to encourage students to do so on their own as an extracurricular activity outside this course as this is a recognised industry standard for product management.

The aim is to encourage students to do so on their own as an extracurricular activity outside this course as this is a recognised industry standard for product management.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX9154.

Managing with Digital Technology aims to increase technical literacy of managers and leaders. The main objective of this course is to give managers a high-level overview of the fundamental concepts, main topics and problems in computer science and information technology and how they relate to business settings, and thus equip them to make better decisions regarding applications of technology, even if they are not technologists themselves. This course takes a top-down approach and emphasises high-level mastery of important concepts in computer science and information technology. Students who successfully complete this course will feel confident in any technology organisation and will have an appreciation for the problems in the field, how they affect or constrain business decisions and how it all works.

The course prepares students for product-management roles. Product manager is increasingly becoming the job of choice for MBA students. Similarly, more and more industries, especially traditional service industries, are creating their own products to deliver more capabilities to their customers and require new capabilities from their managers. Being a product manager requires similar skills to a CEO, which combined with the perceived attractiveness of working in the tech industry, makes it an attractive career path for graduating MBA and management students. A successful product manager needs to master the business side of developing a product as well as be able to interact with a wide range of technical and non-technical stakeholders - from customers through to product engineers and user experience specialists.

Managing with Digital Technology equips founders to succeed in technology endeavors. Successful start-up founders will come across technology from day zero. Virtually every business idea today involves technology - often entire stacks of various technologies. Founders with a non-technical background must rely entirely on their technical co-founders, if they are lucky, or on the word of developers and other technologists they hire, to help them realise their dream. They are often faced with difficult choices and this course aims to equip them with the knowledge and confidence to make informed choices not just in business but in technology as well.
contentlets.title: Managing with Digital Technology

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9155.


We are facing increasingly complex problems that emerge in all aspects of our work and life in a VUCA (volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous) world. To thrive in today’s business climate, integrative problem-solving skills are critical to every business leader and professional.


The Strategic Consulting Project provides you with the opportunity to develop and practise your problem-solving skills by integrating various tools you have acquired during your MBA (Specialised) studies. By investigating a particular strategic issue in an organisation, working as a team on the client issue, identifying solutions for that issue, and presenting recommendations to the client with rigorous logic and practical solutions, you are prepared during this process to become effective leaders and innovators.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"90e79462dba17050be4672f5f39619ff","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Project Scope Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

In this team presentation, you will summarise your project scope to your Supervisor and Course Coordinator for feedback and improvement before presenting to your client. This 20 minute presentation (plus 10 minutes of Q&A) will be recorded for assessment purposes. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO14","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Three reflective blog posts of 250-300 words outlining what you are learning/have learned about working as a team member and how best to contribute to the team, as well as practical steps to improve your own contribution and resolve any issues with the effectiveness of the team, both currently and into the future. Please ensure that you also reflect on what the team is doing to focus on client success. These blog posts should be submitted to the Supervisor (via Moodle) in Weeks 3, 8 and 13. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO13","cl_id":"90e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO14","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Final Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The team will develop a 30-minute presentation and be prepared for a 10-minute Q&A session (total of 40 minutes). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO13","cl_id":"90e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO14","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"94e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9ce7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961905","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a0e7d462dba17050be4672f5f3961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

The Final Report will be a team report (assessed individually) and will be based on your presentations, with appendices that provide the data behind your research, your interview notes, any analysis you have undertaken, and any other material to support your recommendations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9156 - Entrepreneurship and Innovation","description":"

This course suits individuals looking to build their strategic abilities around entrepreneurship and the innovation associated with entrepreneurship. It provides exposure to both the fundamentals of business innovation and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating and moving business ideas forward. The course uniquely exposes students to current ideas and thoughts from innovators, venture capital (VC) groups, and successful start-up CEOs within the Sydney ecosystem.


Two streams of entrepreneurship are covered in the course: startup creation and startup innovation. Specific methodologies covered include integrated experiences of Design Thinking and The Lean Startup.


This is an opportunity to learn about venture creation, startup resourcing, strategy and management, design and innovation involving your own startup. Entrepreneurship & Innovation is a hot topic today – many startups continue to raise money through angel investors and VCs, but the road is a challenging one.


Understanding about what makes entrepreneurship and the innovation in startups work is paramount to success. We will help you develop your confidence, your products, your pitch, and your funding to help get you started on the road to your startup success.

contentlets.description:
This course suits individuals looking to build their strategic abilities around entrepreneurship and the innovation associated with entrepreneurship. It provides exposure to both the fundamentals of business innovation and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating and moving business ideas forward. The course uniquely exposes students to current ideas and thoughts from innovators, venture capital (VC) groups, and successful start-up CEOs within the Sydney ecosystem.

Two streams of entrepreneurship are covered in the course: startup creation and startup innovation. Specific methodologies covered include integrated experiences of Design Thinking and The Lean Startup.

This is an opportunity to learn about venture creation, startup resourcing, strategy and management, design and innovation involving your own startup. Entrepreneurship & Innovation is a hot topic today – many startups continue to raise money through angel investors and VCs, but the road is a challenging one.

Understanding about what makes entrepreneurship and the innovation in startups work is paramount to success. We will help you develop your confidence, your products, your pitch, and your funding to help get you started on the road to your startup success.
contentlets.title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9202 - Individual Research Project","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX9202.


Participants in the Master of Business and Technology program may propose to undertake a project as part of the MBT program. The project is the equivalent of one (6 units of credit) course. By undertaking a project, students will be able to investigate a particular area of interest in business and technology and perhaps contribute to the professional body of knowledge in the area.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6232.


There is an explosion of data in the business workplace, but very few managers are equipped with the quantitative skills to make effective use of this data. This course develops expertise in a standard set of statistical and graphical techniques, which will be useful in analysing data. These techniques are widely applied in a number of areas of management, including marketing, finance and economics. The course provides a change in mindset from "statistics can be used to show anything" to "statistics provide a methodology to cope with uncertainty" via the art of statistical thinking, that is, the ability to collect, understand and use data.


A work-based project is a key part of the course.


There are two saturday workshops in DASM. They are compulsory.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6232.

There is an explosion of data in the business workplace, but very few managers are equipped with the quantitative skills to make effective use of this data. This course develops expertise in a standard set of statistical and graphical techniques, which will be useful in analysing data. These techniques are widely applied in a number of areas of management, including marketing, finance and economics. The course provides a change in mindset from "statistics can be used to show anything" to "statistics provide a methodology to cope with uncertainty" via the art of statistical thinking, that is, the ability to collect, understand and use data.

A work-based project is a key part of the course.

There are two saturday workshops in DASM. They are compulsory.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6233.


Any business or organisation is concerned with delivering value to its customers or clients. A company's 'operations' are the direct processes that it uses to create value. These involve transforming various types of inputs into outputs. Operations management is the task of managing these processes. Each company or organisation will have a unique set of operations. This course is concerned with the fundamentals of operations management, covering both service industries and manufacturing. The aim is to give you a set of frameworks and concepts you can use to understand the operations functions and strategies of any company. The course examines the processes at the heart of operations management and ways of achieving excellence. It also looks at the supply chain; both the control of inventory and the way in which coordination between supply chain partners can be achieved. The course ends with the investigation of operational challenges involved in managing projects.


This course has two compulsory saturday workshops.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX6271.


The course is designed for anyone playing a formal or informal role as change agent in an organisation, defining ‘change agent’ very broadly as ‘a person who attempts to positively influence organisational change through his or her own actions and through influencing the actions of others’.


The course will introduce student to a range of:


  • concepts, frameworks, models and theories that can be used to (a) understand organisational change and the key factors and processes that determine the level of success in bringing about change in an organisation and (b) guide a change agent’s thinking and practice 
  • recipes, tools and methods for use in critically important change processes such as: diagnosing what needs to be changed; deciding on the best change to make, devising an effective way of making the change; building the required level of commitment to support and enact the change; handling resistance; implementing a change; and tracking and adapting the change.

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX6272.


The focus in Change Skills is on you and your skills development as a change agent.


In order to gain maximum benefit from the course, it is important to:


  • use the Change Skills Audit to evaluate your skills and to obtain feedback from others who have seen something of your work as a change agent
  • continually apply the ideas in the course in reflecting on your skills, on ways of handling change-management challenges more skilfully, and on ways to develop your skills
  • translate these reflections into action plans and create or take opportunities to implement your action plans during the course.
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f2713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d1","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Analysis of your self-management skills","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The tasks

1. Analyse and evaluate your current skills in self-management, drawing on concepts from Units 1, 2, 3 and 4 (50%) 

  • Identify and analyse two (2) self-management strengths and analyse how they contribute to your effectiveness as a change agent.
  • Identify and analyse two (2) areas for improvement in your self-management and analyse how these improvements will contribute to your effectiveness as a change agent.
  • Support your analysis and evaluation with specific examples and with evidence, including data from the Change Skills Audit about your self-management skills.
  • Relate your analysis and evaluation to the challenges you face and expect to face as a change agent. 

2. Focusing on one area for improvement in your self-management, outline a plan for managing yourself more skilfully, drawing on concepts from Units 1, 2, 3 and 4 (50%)

  • Outline your improvement goal and the steps you will take to achieve it.
  • Identify possible obstacles that you might face in implementing your plan and describe how you will deal with them.
  • Outline how you will monitor and evaluate your progress in implementing your plan.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07717e0ddb613c10be4672f5f3961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4 Part A: After-action review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Drawing on any unit in the course other than Unit 6, analyse your intentional application of a course concept in your work as a change agent.

Address the following topics in your review and structure the review in the following four sections.

Action (Recommended length: 15%)

What did you do to intentionally apply the concept to address the challenge(s) you faced in the situation in which you applied the concept? Outline:

  • the concept that you were applying
  • what you did to apply it
  • your rationale for applying this course concept in the situation.

Results (Recommended length: 15%)

What resulted from your applying the concept? Describe and analyse the impacts on:

  • you, e.g. on your thoughts, feelings and actions
  • others, e.g. their reactions
  • change processes and outcomes.

Insights (Recommended length: 35%)

What did you learn from applying the course concept and reflecting on what you did and the results, e.g. about the course concept, about yourself, about others, about the kind of challenge you were encountering in this situation and/or about effective ways of dealing with the challenge?

Next steps (Recommended length: 35%)

What steps will you take to build on your learning from applying the concept and to further improve your effectiveness in handling similar challenges?

What do you expect to be one significant challenge in taking these steps and how will you address it?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Analysis and evaluation of your use of process facilitation skills in coaching","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Conduct two coaching sessions, in which you use process facilitation skills to assist someone to develop one or more of the skills covered in this course.

1. Analyse incidents or episodes in the coaching sessions, drawing on concepts from Units 1 to 7 (50%)

a. Identify two incidents or episodes in the coaching sessions where you believe that what you did as a coach was effective. Use course concepts to identify what you did, and how and why it was effective.

b. Identify two incidents or episodes in the sessions where you could have been more effective as a coach and process facilitator. Use course concepts to analyse:

  • how and why what you did was not fully effective
  • what you might have done differently and the expected effects on the coachee and the coaching process.

2.    Drawing on concepts from Units 1 to 7, outline two lessons you have learned from the coaching about process facilitation and how they can be applied in your work as a change agent (50%)

Based on your analysis and evaluation of your coaching in the two sessions:

a. identify two lessons you have learned about process facilitation that you could apply in working as a change agent with either individuals or groups

b. explain the relevance of these lessons to your work as a change agent and how implementing these lessons would enhance your effectiveness

c. for each lesson, outline a plan with specific steps that you will take to implement these two lessons in your work

d. identify possible obstacles that you might face in implementing these steps and describe how you will deal with them

e. outline how you will monitor and evaluate your progress in implementing these steps.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4 Part B: Breakthrough skills development plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"
  • Outline a breakthrough skill development plan that focuses on developing a skill that will unlock many possibilities for you – as, for example, a plan for more skilful listening could unlock many possibilities for improved performance, or a plan for managing your confidence or resilience could enable you to handle many different types of situations more skilfully.
  • Clearly identify the skill that is the focus of the plan.
  • Briefly describe the data that indicates that there is a good reason to develop this skill, e.g. Change Skills Audit data, feedback from others, self-observation, etc.
  • Show how developing this skill will unlock many skills development possibilities for you and/or have a widespread impact on your effectiveness as a change agent.
  • Outline your skill development goal and the steps you will take to achieve it.
  • Discuss how you will monitor and evaluate your progress in implementing your plan.
  • Discuss possible obstacles (including any ambivalence or resistance you might feel about implementing your plan) and ways of overcoming them.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fe713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a713e0ddb613c10be4672f5f39619e1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Contribution to Online dialogues 1 to 5","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

There are five assessable online dialogues in Change Skills, together counting towards 30% of the grade. Each dialogue is an important forum for sharing your ideas, experiences and learning with fellow students and with your facilitator.

Week 2: Dialogue 1, Units 1 & 2

Week 4: Dialogue 2, Units 3 & 4

Week 7: Dialogue 3, Units 5, 6 & 7

Week 9: Dialogue 4, Units 8 & 9

Week 11: Dialogue 5, Units 10 & 11
