contentlets.keywords: mbax,graduate certificate in change management,gccm,change skills,mbax6272
contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX6272.

The focus in Change Skills is on you and your skills development as a change agent.

In order to gain maximum benefit from the course, it is important to:

  • use the Change Skills Audit to evaluate your skills and to obtain feedback from others who have seen something of your work as a change agent
  • continually apply the ideas in the course in reflecting on your skills, on ways of handling change-management challenges more skilfully, and on ways to develop your skills
  • translate these reflections into action plans and create or take opportunities to implement your action plans during the course.
contentlets.title: Change Skills

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9273 - Redesigning the Organisation","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX6273


This course focuses on the important structural and cultural elements of an organisation's design, when and why the elements might need to be redesigned and how to redesign them effectively. We consider changes at the level of individual jobs through to strategic options such as mergers, downsizing and restructuring. There is no one perfect design, only an optimal design for each particular time and context. By the end of the course you will be able to:


  • Describe the main features of organisations
  • Assess an organisational design in relation to the strategy and the environment
  • Apply an open-systems perspective to planning for change
  • Identify appropriate interventions
  • Recommend ways to improve the redesign process.

contentlets.description:
NOTE:This course was previously identified as MBAX6273

This course focuses on the important structural and cultural elements of an organisation's design, when and why the elements might need to be redesigned and how to redesign them effectively. We consider changes at the level of individual jobs through to strategic options such as mergers, downsizing and restructuring. There is no one perfect design, only an optimal design for each particular time and context. By the end of the course you will be able to:

  • Describe the main features of organisations
  • Assess an organisational design in relation to the strategy and the environment
  • Apply an open-systems perspective to planning for change
  • Identify appropriate interventions
  • Recommend ways to improve the redesign process.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"AGSM9274 - Systems for Change","description":"

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MBAX6274


Contemporary organisations function in complex and turbulent environments. The demands of these environments necessitate change, both episodic and continual. Systems for Change analyses change within organisations using a systems perspective. It views the organisation as a system comprising interdependent units, processes, procedures, rules and events, which can be leveraged to enable successful change. Further, the organisation is an open system, positioned in and influenced by its external environment. The course highlights the uncertain and paradoxical nature of change and stresses the need for those involved in initiating and sustaining change to embrace complexity, and adopt an open-systems perspective in their work. The course also affirms the need for those involved in change management to continually assess their personal effectiveness and pursue improvement plans.


Three central themes are evident throughout Systems for Change. Firstly, we recognise that organisations are complex and that they are positioned in complex, turbulent environments. Secondly, we propose that sustaining change in this context is critical. Thirdly, we argue that a systems thinking? perspective is essential for change agents. We offer a variety of approaches to sustain continuous change in this complex milieu, including individual perspectives (e.g. paradoxical thinking), structural perspectives (e.g. ambidexterity), cultural perspectives (e.g. broad-based diversity) and leveraging established organisational sub-systems (e.g. the employment relations sub-system).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"224a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619c8","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Integrative change project final report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

To complete this assessment, you will submit a report of a plan for a change, and the analyses you have undertaken in order to develop your plan. You will not be required to implement the plan. We are looking for evidence of ability to apply course concepts to the analysis of a situation and to develop recommendations for improvement.

Your report needs to show evidence of understanding of concepts across the whole course (i.e. not just one or two Units) and from Approaches to Change. You also need to show your ability to integrate concepts, i.e. use more than one concept to analyse an issue or develop a strategy, and consider the links between the concepts.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e24a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e24a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e24a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ea4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ee4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a4a6c36dbe1b050be4672f5f396190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Integrative change project proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

You are required to submit a 2,500-word account of your intended project. This is your proposal for your intended project. Think in terms of including sufficient information for your client to be clear on what you propose to do, and why and how you intend to go about it. Clarifying your thinking in this way at this point will provide a healthy platform to carry out the project within the given timeframes. Of course, this is a statement of your intention at this point in time, and things may change as you proceed. These changes will be reflected in your final report, but there needs to be a clear starting point.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e24a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e24a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ea4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ee4a2c36dbe1b050be4672f5f39619c8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"874a6c36dbe1b050be4672f5f3961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Dialogue Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You are required to participate in four (4) online dialogues. Each dialogue is worth equal marks (5%) and feedback will be provided after the four dialogues are complete. Each dialogue will commence on the Monday of the designated week and conclude on the following Sunday. The schedule is as follows:

  • Online dialogue 1 – Week 3
  • Online dialogue 2 – Week 5
  • Online dialogue 3 – Week 8
  • Online dialogue 4 – Week 10

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6303.


The AGSM9303 AGSM Masterclass is a new elective has a strong emphasis on shaping the agenda of the future. It provides MBA candidates with injections of global thought leadership, future scenario planning, frameworks and conceptual tools as well as clinics to solve real dilemmas. The Series consist of ½ day workshops jointly facilitated by industry leaders and academic staff on different contemporary topics. Six workshops will be offered each year.  Over a maximum of 24 months students need to attend five and successful complete assessment tasks. Topics will vary each year.  Example topics include: Digital disruption/ disruptive technology; Design thinking; Systems thinking; Agility; Operational excellence; Social media strategy; ‘big data’; Storytelling and narrative; Creativity; Start-ups.

NOTE: This course was offered as MNGT6370 prior to 2022. 


FMS is a 12 week course that includes a 3 day compulsory residential.


The course is an academically-grounded orientation to the AGSM MBA (Executive) program. It is intended to provide a cohort experience and to help students acquire a range of useful strategies and skills for enhancing their managerial effectiveness, as well as for engaging productively with the MBA(Executive) course concepts and their colleagues throughout their program. The three themes addressed are managing your learning, learning together, and managerial skill development.


Learning in this course occurs through a combination of mindful engagement with reading course materials and assigned articles, completing written exercises, self-assessments, repeated 360 degree feedback, peer coaching, team-based case analysis, skill development planning, and action learning.


Please Note: Existing AGSM students who have already completed any MBAX or MNGT coded courses will need to contact the AGSM Student Experience Team for assistance with enrolment into this course. 02 9931 9400 studentexperience@agsm.edu.au

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was offered as MNGT6370 prior to 2022. 

FMS is a 12 week course that includes a 3 day compulsory residential.

The course is an academically-grounded orientation to the AGSM MBA (Executive) program. It is intended to provide a cohort experience and to help students acquire a range of useful strategies and skills for enhancing their managerial effectiveness, as well as for engaging productively with the MBA(Executive) course concepts and their colleagues throughout their program. The three themes addressed are managing your learning, learning together, and managerial skill development.

Learning in this course occurs through a combination of mindful engagement with reading course materials and assigned articles, completing written exercises, self-assessments, repeated 360 degree feedback, peer coaching, team-based case analysis, skill development planning, and action learning.

Please Note: Existing AGSM students who have already completed any MBAX or MNGT coded courses will need to contact the AGSM Student Experience Team for assistance with enrolment into this course. 02 9931 9400 studentexperience@agsm.edu.au

NOTE: This course was previously identified as MNGT6371.


This course explores selected theories and concepts of change management. You will identify the key skills you need to lead and implement change. We explore different perspectives on managing change, your personal change competencies, how to build readiness for change, change leadership, action research as a means of driving change, and strategic change. The course helps you to develop skills in these areas and broadens your competence to help organisations manage change. It uses a mixture of group-based activities, personal reflection and experiential exercises to explore a wide range of topics.

contentlets.description:
NOTE: This course was previously identified as MNGT6371.

This course explores selected theories and concepts of change management. You will identify the key skills you need to lead and implement change. We explore different perspectives on managing change, your personal change competencies, how to build readiness for change, change leadership, action research as a means of driving change, and strategic change. The course helps you to develop skills in these areas and broadens your competence to help organisations manage change. It uses a mixture of group-based activities, personal reflection and experiential exercises to explore a wide range of topics.

Business","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6582.


The forces of globalisation have increased the permeability of traditional boundaries around countries, economies and industries. These forces include the expansion of international trade and investment, the growth of multinational corporations (MNCs), the ability of information and communications technology to span time and distance, and the shift of the worldâ??s economic centre of gravity from the West to Asia. Because of globalisation, the environment of business is now more complex, more dynamic, more uncertain and more competitive than ever before.


This course examines important strategic, organisational and operational issues from the perspective of managers working for local Australian firms or subsidiaries of MNCs based in Australia, as well as entrepreneurs who are looking to expand their venture overseas. Its main objective is to develop an understanding of the international business opportunities and challenges facing these firms and individuals, and how they can best address these issues when competing in the global marketplace.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a85250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e5","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part A: Interim Presentation of Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The major assessment piece in this course is a team project looking at Internationalisation. This assessment has two related parts: a presentation (Part A), and a final report (Part B). In addition, there is a separate opportunity to evaluate your peers’ input to the team processes and work.

Student teams will be formed to reflect cultural and industry diversity at the beginning of the course. Each team of students will consider themselves as the internationalisation project team of an Australian firm, and select a country and conduct an assessment of its attractiveness and feasibility for this Australian firm in a specific industry (e.g. medical devices) to invest and do business there.

To ensure that no two teams will be conducting an assessment of the same country or industry, team coordinators should email the Course Coordinator (Email: janexjq@unsw.edu.au) the team’s country selection (with first and second choice) at the earliest convenience, and the selection approval will be made on a first-come-first-served basis, according to the date and time the email is received.

Each team will have 15 minutes to present an interim report of the internationalisation project to get feedback from the class and class facilitator before submitting the final report. This presentation will be followed by a 10-minute Q&A.

Participation: All members should participate (at least two presenters present the 15-minute presentation, and all members participate in Q&A. Members who don’t present should try their best to contribute to the Q&A.). Part A will be assessed individually on their contribution.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"605250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"645250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"785250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"305250eadb617050be4672f5f39619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Individual course reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

At the conclusion of the course, you are required to submit course reflections synthesising the lessons learned from the 12 Units.

Your reflection about how this course is relevant to your current profession and future business endeavours is only shared with the Class Facilitator.

Topics can include, but are not limited to:

1.    how this course has provided analytical frameworks for you to analyse the industry and business that you are engaged in

2.    an analysis of the business/industry of interest, with one or a few frameworks in the course

3.    how your understanding has changed at a personal level, if at all, as a consequence of this course

4.    identify a few critical next-steps that you might want to engage with in terms of professional development in a globalised world.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"605250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"645250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"785250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"815290eadb617050be4672f5f3961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part B: Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In the final report, continue the work you started in Assessment 2: Part A - the presentation. This report has several specific sections that you need to include. These are detailed below.

1.    The first part of your report presents the country’s PESTEL (Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Environmental and Legal) factors and how these create business opportunities or challenges for Australian firms.

2.    The report should  focus on a small number of most important factors (e.g. demographic factors and labour cost for a labour-intensive project, and internet infrastructure for an offshore IT support hub), instead of giving equal weight to a large number of factors.

3.    The second part of your report should propose a plan of actions for an Australian firm to enter and conduct business in the country examined. There are two options to organise this section of your report:

    Option 1:

       If your project is the foreign expansion of a well-established firm, your report might include, but not be limited to, the following sections:

•     Recommended business investment/operation (e.g. R&D) and rationale

•     Recommended entry mode/strategy (e.g. joint venture) and rationale

•     Recommended organisational structure for the operation and rationale

•     Recommended human resource plan and rationale

•     Follow-up action and next steps.

     Option 2:

•     If your project is a start-up venture or born-global, you can refer to the Tool Box in Unit 10 (page 8) which provides you with the Business Model Canvas comprising the factors you need to address such as customer segments, customer relationships, channels, value propositions, key activities, key resources, key partners, cost structure and revenue structure. Your report should address these issues in an international context.

Your report should also include:

•     An executive summary (fewer than 150 words)

•     A brief description of the firm (can be real or hypothetical) and industry

•     A conclusion that draws together details of the report, briefly detailing the main findings.

Use of tables and figures is highly encouraged, with all tables and figures being numbered, titled and explained thoroughly in text. Bullet points can be used sparingly, but each point requires clear explanation in text.

Part B will be assessed as a group.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"605250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"645250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"685250eadb617050be4672f5f39619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"705250eadb617050be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"785250eadb617050be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc5290eadb617050be4672f5f3961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Much of the learning in this course comes from interaction between participants. Participation is evaluated by:

a.    face-to-face contribution to the intensive weekends (10%) and

b.    contribution to Moodle forums (15%), e.g. quality of the Opinion Piece and replies to others’ Opinion Piece.

Students need to demonstrate a good knowledge of the Unit being discussed, and make an effort to constructively facilitate dialogue between class members.

The quality of contributions to the class discussion will be reflected in the marks for participation. Specifically, students can:

1.    prepare for the intensive weekends by reading course material thoroughly and carefully

2.    act as a member of the discussion panel volunteerily or by invitation

3.    present and share their own business case with the class

4.    introduce guest speakers to the class

5.    post articles or other information related to this course on Moodle forums

6.    actively participate and lead group projects

7.    complete any specialised forum activities such as the ‘opinion piece’ activity in Week 7. Each student will publish an Opinion Piece (500 words approx.) in the Moodle forum to elaborate on their critical thoughts about an issue related to international business and globalisation. To express your view and also stimulate others’ thoughts, an interesting and thought-provoking topic and engaging writing style are essential. Readers are encouraged to reply to opinion pieces and these replies will be evaluated in terms of their quantity and quality. When publishing your article on Moodle, please use the article title as the title of your thread, and the IB class you are in (e.g. Sydney Intensive INT 1) before the article, because this forum is visible to students from all IB classes for a collective learning experience. For typical business articles by columnists, please see http://www.biznews.com/category/columnists/lucy-kellaway/. No referencing is needed.

Note that in the intensive weekends, having a clear name tag is essential for the Class Facilitator to record the participation mark accurately.

Experience","description":"

NOTE:This course was previously identified as MNGT6583. 


The forces of globalisation have increased the permeability of traditional boundaries around countries, economies and industries. These forces include the expansion of international trade and investment, the growth of multinational corporations (MNCs), and significant improvements in communication and transportation technologies. These technological and transportation advances have facilitated the appearance of a whole new set of international entrepreneurs who, taking advantage of the reduced distance across markets, have been extremely successful in spawning a new breed of born global ventures and initiatives. Being able to identify and capitalise on the opportunities arising from this new world order is something that cannot be learned without being exposed more intensely to the new global business environment.


However, these forces shrinking the 'distance' between countries have not emerged without controversy, and thus they have failed to transform our world into a fully integrated 'global village'. Tensions across ethnic, religious and linguistic divides, as well as other home-grown regulatory efforts protecting local interests, have counterbalanced these centripetal forces, creating a more complex, uncertain and competitive business environment than ever before. The resulting 'semi-globalised' world represents an environment in which socioeconomic and political boundaries have a central and enduring role in shaping the activities of MNCs and international entrepreneurs. This new reality also calls for a reassessment of what it means to be a manager within MNCs. Managers are now pressed to not only provide benefits from commonalities across markets, but to also embrace differences among them. It is this need to be aware and to fully comprehend these differences that requires a new type of MNC leader or entrepreneur: what is called a cosmopolitan leader.


This course offers one possible path towards the personal developmental processes AGSM students need to embrace in becoming cosmopolitan leaders. The course combines different in-class activities with experiential learning based on first-hand encounters with businesses environments that are culturally, physically and institutionally distant from the typical experiences of managers and entrepreneurs working in Australia. While the chosen locations (i.e. countries) may vary each time this course is delivered, the activities executed locally and in the countries visited remain aligned with the course aims described in the ensuing section.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d4","name":"Independent research - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Pre departure work: Reading Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

You will publish a Reading Reflection of approximately 500 words in the Moodle forum that elaborates on your own ideas about a particular topic related to the course materials (including readings and videos) provided in Moodle. To express your view and also to stimulate others’ thoughts, an interesting and thought-provoking topic and engaging writing style are essential. Fellow students are encouraged to reply to this report and these replies will be evaluated in terms of their quantity and quality. This piece is expected to be 500 words, and maximum no more than 700 words.

When publishing your article in Moodle, please use the article title as the title of your thread. For examples of typical business articles by columnists, please see http://www.biznews.com/category/columnists/lucy-kellaway/. No referencing is needed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Deep reflection exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"30","description":"

Following the field-study tour, you are required to submit the following, synthesising the lessons learned from the whole experience (Stage 1 plus Stage 2 activities):

Part A: an opinion piece (700 words) published in the Moodle forum that summarises the key insights you gained during the tour and generates online discussion.

Part B: a self-reflection piece (800 words) submitted in Moodle via Turnitin that discusses how this whole experience has changed your previous understanding and viewpoint. It should explicitly attend to whether, as a consequence of this whole experience, you feel more prepared to effectively work with people from a different cultural background from yourself. Finally, the report needs to identify a few critical next-steps that you might want to take in terms of professional development that are inspired by this tour.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Team project presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

You will work within a small team of classmates to investigate the local environment and analyse how environmental factors (e.g. economic and cultural) affect doing business in this country. For example, teams may be asked to go to a local fresh market and interview local residents about their daily consumption behaviours. The Course Facilitator will conduct a short session to prepare each team for their task in advance.

After on-site investigation, each team is required to develop and deliver a 10-minute presentation to the rest of the group synthesising the research they have performed assessing the particular market or social environment they have studied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9d24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Daily facilitation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"20","description":"

Student teams will act as ‘Lead facilitators’ for one to two days of the tour. Each team of facilitators is responsible for:

1.    conducting research about organisations that we are visiting during the days they are allocated and for forming meaningful questions for the class to consider before the visits

2.    conducting research about each speaker’s background and introducing the speaker to the class before their talk

3.    gift giving (AGSM will provide the gifts) – presenting gifts and thanking the speakers in a manner that is appropriate to the local culture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619e1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Pre-departure work: Self-introduction","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

You will post  an informative self-intrudction to introduce yourself to the class. A sample introduction of the course facilitator will be provided in Moodle for your reference. Introduce yourself to the class not just as a business person or professional, but also as a ‘whole person’ with hobbies and personality, and leave an impression on others who have never met you until we get together in China.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation: Face to face","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

You are required to engage in all scheduled activities (Stages 1 and 2). Additionally, you are expected to actively and enthusiastically contribute in all discussions and exercises locally and during the field-study tour.

Much of the learning in this course comes from interaction between participants.

You need to demonstrate a good knowledge of the IB course materials, and make an effort to constructively facilitate dialogue between class members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d524b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619e6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation: Online","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Online participation, including commenting on each other’s pre-departure reports and post-tour Opinion Pieces.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4124b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"dd24b93edba9b050be4672f5f39619e3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/AGSM9583.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
